PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef: Oil Exploration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that:

'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978 be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Grape Spirit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 1983 Budget imposition of the excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine places at risk the future of the fortified wine industry in Australia.
That the requirement to pay the excise within 7 days of the fortification occurring is inequitable.
That the excise will be reflected in increased costs to the consumers of fortified wines of up to 100 per cent and consumer choice will be restricted.
That this will cause reduced fortified wine sales which will result in reduced intake of grapes from grapegrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and either withdraw this tax or modify its method of application and collection.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submits that:

Although many occurrences of sexual harassment in the workforce have been reported to various State government authorities, such as the Victorian Commission for Equal Opportunity, the real incidence of sexual intimidation in employment will not be known, or countered, until a national policy towards sexual harassment is determined and implemented.

1. The National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation be commissioned to conduct a nation-wide study of discrimination based on sex, both in the private sector and the Public Service, with a view to advising the Government on the development of national policy.
2. The major priority of such a study should be to determine a legally- enforceable definition of sexual harassment.

3. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations should bring forward in Parliament legislation, arising from such a study, to outlaw discrimination and intimidation in employment based on sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We urge the Government to declare a moratorium on uranium mining and treatment in Australia;
We urge the Government to repudiate any commitment of a non-Labor government to the mining, processing or export of Australia's uranium;
We urge the Government to not permit the mining, processing or export of uranium pursuant to agreements entered into contrary to ALP policy, and
We urge the Government to discontinue the Roxby uranium mine development.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Force Reserves: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That as Mr R. J. L. Hawke has publicly stated:
(1) 'The Defence Force Reserves are the backbone of our nation's defence',
(2) the Defence Force Reserves are a highly economical and viable means of training men and women to serve Australia in times of emergency,
(3) the reserves are composed of volunteers dedicated to Australia.

Furthermore, we the undersigned recognise that members of the reserves are required to maintain levels of efficiency at least equivalent to those of the permanent forces, and that members of reserves spend much of their own time and money towards reserve training obligations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government recognise the role played by the reserves in serving Australia, that reserve pays and allowances are already far below the levels for equivalent work in the general workforce, and that therefore the proposed introduction of taxation to the meagre pays earned by members of the Defence Force Reserves is a poor way of saying thank you.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned with the cut in funding to the Brisbane Airport, concerned that this cut means loss of jobs, concerned that this cut could seriously affect the economy of Queensland:
Humbly petition the Senate to request the Australian Government to:
1. Reserve its decision to cut funding to the Brisbane Airport.
2. Abide by the guarantee given by the Minister for Housing and Construction that the Airport would receive priority funding.
3. Assure the citizens of Queensland that the Brisbane Airport as the domestic and economic gateway to this State will be fully completed by 1987.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We undersigned citizens of Australia,
Believing that men and women are equal but different,
Convinced that Australia can provide equal opportunity for all citizens without foreign treaties,
Concerned that the U.N. Discrimination Convention would give a Communist- dominated international committee the power to judge Australia's laws,
Humbly petition that the Honourable members of the Senate will not support the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 or the Commonwealth laws to achieve its aims.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with notice of intention to withdraw a notice of motion, given on 22 September, I now withdraw Business of the Senate, notice of motion No. 1, standing in my name, for the disallowance of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) (Amendment) Ordinance 1982, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 95 of 1982 and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910. Mr President, I seek leave to make a brief statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The notice of motion for disallowance was originally given on 1 June on the basis of the concern of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances over section 4 of the Ordinance, which, as I said at the time, appears to remove existing rights and claims with retrospective effect. The Committee has since had quite extensive correspondence with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and has examined the Ordinance in detail in the course of several meetings. It was the majority view of the Committee that, on balance, the motion for disallowance should not be proceeded with. I seek leave to have a fuller statement of the Committee's consideration of this matter incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The aim of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) (Amendment) Ordinance 1982 is to amend the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance 1955 to exclude the estate of a deceased person from recovering damages for loss of earning capacity during the years lost to that person by his or her premature death. The amendment was introduced following the recent decision by the High Court in Fitch v Hyde-Cates (1982) 56 ALJR 260, which alerted the community to the anomaly in the New South Wales counterpart of the Principal Ordinance. Under this anomaly, a defendant may, in certain circumstances, be liable not only to the victim's dependants for their financial loss, but also to the victim's estate for his or her loss of earning capacity during the period of life curtailed by the accident causing premature death-the so-called ''lost years''. Section 4 of the amending Ordinance prevents the bringing of actions under this ''lost years'' rule for fatalities that occurred over the past six years (the applicable limitation period in the Australian Capital Territory).

The Regulations and Ordinances Committee has long held the view that extensive retrospective provisions in subordinate legislation-even when they confer a benefit-are prima facie objectionable. In this case, the Committee put its view strenuously to the Attorney-General, demanding an explanation of the importance and necessity of a retrospective provision which removes the right to the additional action identified by the High Court decision in Fitch v Hyde-Cates. The Committee notes that the amending Ordinance does not affect any existing right to damages for actual loss suffered either by dependants of the deceased under the Compensation (Fatal Injuries) Ordinance 1968 or by the estate under the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance 1955.

The effect of the amending Ordinance is to place on an equal footing all cases under the Principal Ordinance by denying anyone the advantage of the duplication of liability uncovered by the High Court decision.

The Committee acknowledges that the aim of the amending Ordinance is to take away what a number of Judges of the High Court and the Attorney-General describe as an unfair advantage. However, the Committee was particularly concerned that the retrospectivity did not penalise financially or otherwise disadvantage those who had already begun legal action under the ''lost years'' rule-particularly those whose claim might be in the course of being enforced in the Court, but also those entitled to enforce a claim who had not yet done so. The Committee has been informed that all actions begun at the time of the introduction of the Ordinance have been settled on the basis of payment of the plaintiff's costs, and that there are now no outstanding claims before the Court.

A minority of the Committee is of the view that the circumstances surrounding the introduction of the amending Ordinance do not excuse the reliance on retrospectivity, which is in principle objectionable. The question before the Committee was whether the retrospective operation of section 4 offends the established principles and criteria under which it examines subordinate legislation. Most relevant was the second of the Committee's principles: whether section 4 of the amending Ordinance did ''trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties'' (I emphasise ''unduly''). If the committee were to find that the provision did unduly trespass, it could move for disallowance and perhaps in so doing, suggest a remedy pursuant to principle (d), under which the Committee examines matters of subordinate legislation which go beyond administrative detail and ''amount to substantive legislation which should be a matter for parliamentary enactment''. The Committee has been recently examining principle ( d) as it relates to ACT Ordinances. It entertained the possibility of seeking to have the retrospective provision included in a Bill for parliamentary determination.

The Committee appreciated the need to balance claims about the social need for the retrospective provision against its legal effect, particularly the effect on any claims that might be in the course of being enforced in the courts, and on any others where proceedings might be in preparation or contemplation but not yet issued at the time of the making of the Ordinance. The majority of the Committee decided, on balance, not to move for disallowance of the Ordinance. Although retrospective provisions are prima facie objectionable, the majority view was that in this instance the circumstances were such that there was no undue trespass on personal rights and liberties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that 11 sitting days after today I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Fireworks (Amendment) Ordinance 1983, as contained in the Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 8 of 1983 and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed.
Mr President, I seek leave to make a brief statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This notice concerns the Fireworks (Amendment) Ordinance 1983. The Committee has some concern about the reversal of onus of proof on a defendant to establish that he or she acted on reasonable grounds. I seek leave to have a fuller statement of the Committee's concern incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The purpose of this Ordinance, according to the Explanatory Statement, is to bring the law relating to the sale, manufacture and use of fireworks in the Australian Capital Territory into line with that applying in New South Wales.
The Committee is concerned at section 4 of the Ordinance which inserts a new section 3 in the Principal Ordinance, containing new sub-sections 3 (2) and (3) which provide as follows:

(2) A person shall not sell fireworks (other than caps, confetti bombs, model rocket propellant devices, snaps for bon-bon crackers, sparklers and streamer cones) to a person under the age of 18 years.
Penalty: $500.

(3) It is a defence in proceedings for an offence against sub-section (2) if the defendant establishes that he believed on reasonable grounds that the person to whom the fireworks were sold was of or above the age of 18 years.

The Committee is concerned that the defence provided by sub-section (3) places on the defendant the onus of establishing that he or she believed on reasonable grounds that the purchaser was aged 18 or more. It may be possible to revise this provision so as to minimise the onus placed on the defendant.

The Committee has sought the views of the Minister for Territories and Local Government on this matter. As today is the last day in which such notice may be given, the Committee has given notice to preserve its rights while awaiting a reply from the Minister.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENT) BILL 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend laws relating to companies and securities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter of privilege. On 14 September 1983 I was reported in the Australian Financial Review, under the heading 'Caucus query on Government tactics in Hope inquiry', as having questioned the line of cross-examination of Mr David Combe before the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. In the article in question, the journalist, Mr Paul Malone, reported inter alia that:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Nick Bolkus said he had seen reports of the Government counsel Mr Michael McHugh, QC, and the ASIO counsel, Mr Stephen Charles, QC, had adopted a line of questioning leading to the suggestion that Mr Combe was disloyal or a traitor because he opposed the previous Government's policy supporting a boycott of the Moscow olympics and the trade sanctions against Russia.
Senator Bolkus asked whether this line of questioning was consistent as the Labor Party had also opposed the sanctions.
The Attorney-General, Senator Evans said if Senator Bolkus's information was the case, it was more than likely part of a general line of cross-examination.

Following this report, and on 15 September, during a public session of the same Royal Commission, a number of references and allegations were made about me which led to my personal explanation in this chamber on 20 September 1983. These allegations were firstly made by Mr McHugh, QC, representing the Government. In part of what can be assessed as an orchestrated passage, he claimed that my comments were those made by 'someone who does not read the transcript'. He was followed by Mr Charles, QC, counsel for ASIO, who alleged that the statements I was reported to have made indicated that I 'had failed to understand the position' that counsel were putting before the Royal Commission. Mr Charles further alleged that I 'was making angry comments according to the Australian Financial Review, demanding that Mr McHugh and I both be pulled into line by the Attorney-General'. The comments were interlaced by some trivial comments from the Royal Commissioner.

Any reading of the report in the Australian Financial Review shows quite clearly that the statements of counsel were inaccurate. I showed quite clearly in my personal explanation in this chamber on 20 September 1983 that not only had I not made any angry demands but also that my complaint, as it has been called, was based on an adequate and accurate reading of the transcripts. I am now amazed that counsel were so sensitive to a mere inquiry as to their performance, for which, need I say, the public is paying a high price. In my statement to the chamber I indicated the line of questioning pursued by counsel. The transcripts, as I read them out at that stage-I shall quote some of them again-show the following: On 31 August 1983 Mr Charles, QC, asked Mr Combe:
Well, you were doing your best, were you not, to overturn sanctions and their effect on your visit to Moscow?
On 7 September 1983, as recorded at page 4724 of the transcript, Mr McHugh asked:
You appreciated, of course, that those proposals were not seen by the Liberal- Country Party government as being in Australia's interests?
On the next page he asked:
Well, whether it was designed for that purpose or not, you appreciated that your proposals would undermine the policies of the elected government of Australia?
He went on to ask:
Whether you liked them or not, the sanctions were the nation's policies, were not they?
On page 4726 Mr McHugh asked Mr Combe:
You have used the word 'conflict'. I have used the words 'sap and undermine'. Your proposals were designed to sap and undermine the policies of the elected government of Australia, were they not?

It is also quite apparent from the transcripts that the Commissioner understood what counsel were about, and I made that point in this place on 20 September 1983. On page 4728 of the transcript the Commissioner said to Mr Combe:
The position is this, is it not, tell me if it is wrong, you disagreed very strongly with those policies?

Those policies, of course, were those of the Fraser Government. I went on to assert that my reported statements were accurate and that counsel had reassessed the value of the line of questioning they were pursuing. I concluded by saying:

I regret that this explanation has been made necessary by behaviour of counsel, which behaviour I have found not only personally offensive but also offensive to my rights and role as a member of this Parliament.

This has then led to the most recent irrational, uncontrolled series of comments made against me in the Royal Commission by Mr Charles, QC. On 28 September 1983, on page 5532 of the transcript-I shall quote the whole paragraph because it is the basis of my claim-Mr Charles is reported as saying:

Now, your Honour, there are not, and have not been, many light moments in this case, but Senator Bolkus is to be thanked for producing a high percentage of them. Among other things he was apparently trying to arrange dinner for Mr Combe for last week with chicken kiev on the menu. Now, what is clear, your Honour, is that Senator Bolkus, unfortunately, does not understand court proceedings; still less does he understand the proceedings of this commission, but if he continues to drop the suggestion that Mr McHugh and I are liars, in the wrong place, he may rapidly find out more about legal proceedings.

Mr President, I submit that these comments constitute the breach of privilege and I contend they do so for a number of reasons. The comments are a deliberate attempt to discredit me as a member of this Senate, and to bring me into contempt. In the words on precedents in Odgers, at page 648, they constitute an 'offensive and scurrilous personal attack with the purpose of holding me up to ridicule or contempt'. They are, as anyone can see-even members of the Opposition in this instance-misleading; they are a mala fide report of my comments and an inaccurate reading of my comments in this place. They are also a personal attack on my character, not only as a member of the Senate but also as one who is qualified and has practised in law. Coming from counsel in a royal commission, the remarks are intimidatory. This intimidatory nature is of course aggravated by the position held by the person making the comments.

In essence, the statements are threats directed at and based on an inaccurate interpretation of my comments in this chamber and are, to quote Odgers once again, 'intended to influence and intimidate me in my conduct in the Senate. They attempt to impute, inappropriately, conduct for the express purpose of discrediting and silencing'. I refer to page 654 of Odgers. At the least, the breach of parliamentary privilege is that they relate to comments I have made in the House or incidental to my functions as a member of this Parliament. I agree that in the world of politics there should be greater tolerance than what is normally available in courts of law. However, these comments, because of the reasons I have described, should not be tolerated. To ignore them in this case is to breed abuse. In summing up, let me quote very quickly from a section of an editorial in the Australian on 1 and 2 October-last weekend. The editorial said:

Having denigrated, under privilege, Senator Bolkus' competence as a lawyer, ASIO's counsel, Mr Charles QC, then warned the Senator that he could be subjected to legal proceedings. Whatever their party allegiances, all Australians with some respect for free speech and the parliamentary institution, would trust that this threat would have no more serious consequences than those previously made.

I am concerned at these comments. I am further disturbed that they have been allowed in the proceedings of a royal commission and with the acquiescence of the Commissioner. They follow a number of other related incidents which are of concern. I refer to the action against Peter Duncan, a member of the State Parliament in South Australia, the comments made about Mr Richard Hall on 28 September 1983 and the allegations that the film Allies was funded by the KGB. They were all unsubstantiated allegations, and have not been proven since. All these attacks have been allowed to be made under the privilege of the Royal Commissions Act and with the acquiescence of the Royal Commissioner. To me, this personal denigration of individuals in this uncontrolled manner should not be allowed to continue but that, of course, is up to the judgment of His Honour.

In closing, Mr President, I contend that the powers of parliamentary privilege vested in this Parliament under the Australian Constitution override whatever protection may be claimed by counsel under the Royal Commissions Act, especially section 73 thereof. I claim that these statements of counsel constitute a breach of parliamentary privilege and, accordingly, I move:

That the comments of Mr Charles QC in the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies and especially those comments referring to Senator Bolkus on page 5532 thereof be referred to the Senate Privileges Committee for consideration and report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had no notice that Senator Bolkus was going to move this motion but I suppose I should not be taken by surprise; after all, Senator Bolkus's parliamentary leader threatened the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) with breach of privilege proceedings for daring to comment on the proceedings of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies and now a member of the Australian Labor Party is threatening the Commission with breach of privilege proceedings for daring to comment on the Parliament. I think that is the most marvellous demonstration of the devotion to democracy and free debate that exists on that side of the Parliament. I find the whole thing absolutely ludicrous and I think it is a great shame that so much parliamentary time is being wasted on what are essentially arguments caused by the internecine fights of the Labor Party. I now understand why Mr Justice Jim Staples, according to an article in the National Times of 30 September-6 October, had some very unkind things to say about the Labor Party and its carry-on about civil liberties. I will not waste the time of the Senate at this stage by quoting from that article . However, I am sure that many honourable senators opposite will have read it. In listening to their colleague, they might well understand better why this rather unusual article came to be written.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that Senator Bolkus is a member of the Privileges Committee. Certainly the Opposition would not support this reference unless Senator Bolkus gave the clearest indication to the Senate that he would not seek to participate in any Committee deliberation related to the matters he has raised and which he wishes to refer to the Commitee. TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee of Privileges is not a committee of hangmen. That is shameful and absolutely disgusting.

—He will undertake that he would not wish to participate in this Committee whilst it is dealing with the matters he has raised. Mr President, I hear a very excited interjection from behind me. The point I was making was that I have little doubt that Senator Bolkus wishes it to act in one of the ways which I have described. TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister, who said on Radio 6PR in Perth last Tuesday that the clear and unequivocal policy of the South Australian Labor Party was 'for the development of Roxby Downs and that, of course, is totally consistent with Federal policy'? I ask the Minister: When was the decision taken that the development of the Roxby uranium deposit was consistent with Federal policy, in view of the Minister's statement of 12 September in this place that the Roxby question was part of the comprehensive policy review decision?

—I am not familiar with the radio program, the transcript of which Senator Chaney has quoted or purported to quote. I do not know the context in which those remarks appeared. The whole package of submissions on the uranium question is due for consideration by Cabinet later this month, as I have stated here previously. Since I am not familiar with the other matters I will refer them to the Prime Minister to see whether he has any comment to make on them.

—I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that whether or not the Roxby Downs project will receive approval from the Federal Government for the export of uranium is a matter which is still subject to review within the review that he has mentioned?

—The answer is that no application to export uranium from Roxby Downs has been received by the Government; nor is any application likely to be received for very many years hence. Indeed, the economic feasibility study of the whole project being conducted by the company is not scheduled for completion until the end of 1984.

—I direct my question also to the Minister for Resources and Energy. The Minister will be aware that workers employed at the Ranger uranium plant went on strike last week over a health and safety matter. Can the Minister tell the Senate of the circumstances which led to the strike and give us any information about its resolution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of that strike. Indeed, I was at the Ranger mine site and plant last Thursday. From memory, I believe that the strike commenced on the previous Monday. The reason for the strike in the broadest sense was concern by the work force about health and safety issues, in particular arising from an unfortunate incident last July when the industrial or plant water supply and the potable water supply within the plant were interconnected. There were a number of preliminary steps to that interconnection. The interconnection was by way of a flexible coupling, incidentally, which should not have taken place and which one trusts will not happen again in the future. Last week the company agreed to replace the entire potable water supply delivery system within the plant, following the discovery in a blind T-piece of a small quantity of ammonium diuranate, which presumably had entered the potable water supply system following the interconnection of the plant and potable water supply systems and a higher pressure on the plant side than on the potable water supply side. I understand that the work force returned to work at midnight last night.

ANSWER.PARA: When discussing this question with people who are employed at the plant and with the mine management, I made the suggestion, which appeared to me to be well received by both sides, that I contact Mr Cohen and suggest that the Supervising Scientist, Mr Fry, visit the area and spend a few days or perhaps even a week on the site discussing this and other issues with management and the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Make sure that he drinks a bit of the water.

—Senator Chipp has reminded me I am informed that following the discovery of the ammonium diuranate in the blind T-piece, the entire work force was subject to checks to see whether there was any indication that anyone had been contaminated through drinking the water. I understand that the tests were negative. The management has also agreed to employ an additional four or five people, I believe, for general duties in cleaning up the plant and in particular cleaning up dust which accumulates from time to time.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that response. I ask him further whether it is not also a fact that one of the causes of the strike was that the workers at Ranger are not satisfied with the monitoring carried out by the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy. What action can be taken to overcome that problem?

—Although I have received no written communication along the lines indicated by Senator Robertson, it was certainly my clear impression when discussing the issue with the work force-Senator Robertson was also present and took part in those discussions-that the work force is apprehensive about the adequacy of monitoring by the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy. I pass no judgment, incidentally, and I do not believe I am in a position to pass judgment, on whether those fears or apprehensions are merited. But, given that they exist, that was the primary reason that prompted me to suggest that the Supervising Scientist-about whom my clear impression is that the work force does not hold those same reservations or apprehensions-be asked, through Mr Cohen and his Department, to visit the mine site and discuss with management and the workers the specific issues which prompted the strike and the ongoing health and safety requirements.

—I ask the Attorney- General whether he has noted a report of a warning given by the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Burke, who delivered the Sir Norman Cowper Oration in Sydney last Saturday, that the federation was under 'severe threat' as a result of the decision of the High Court of Australia in the Franklin Dam case and that 'the federal system is shaping up for a showdown' . —Premier Burke has his political constituency to attend to, just as Senator Durack has his and others have theirs. My answers to Senator Durack's questions are these: No and no.

Are Commonwealth public servants who are members of the Navy, Air Force and Army reserves granted leave to attend full time training? If so, is this leave granted on full pay? If leave is granted on full pay, what is the maximum period of such leave in each year? Does the reservist collect two pays, that is, his or her pay as a public servant and a pay for the reserve training also?
—I am totally unable to answer that question. I will refer it to the Prime Minister.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I understand that the Government's position on the package of claims by the building industry unions is that the claims should be pursued through an anomalies hearing of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. As I understand that the Government will not state its view until such a hearing, I ask the Minister: Is he able to explain the grounds upon which Mr Weaven of the Australian Council of Trade Unions is able to state that there should not be any difficulty in processing the increases of existing allowances? Is the Government's opposition limited to the $7.50 building industry recovery procedures allowance? Is the Government set to support the other claims that will be made at the time to an anomalies hearing of the Commission?

—We have been through this matter a number of times in the Senate. As I have said on a number of occasions, the Government will make known its attitude at the appropriate time in the course of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearing. I am quite unable to say, and I am not accountable in any way for, what Mr Weaven of the ACTU says or believes. I am not familiar with the statement which he made. I assure the Senate that I am in no way about to explain what Mr Weaven's view of the world might be. I should add that, insofar as the building industry claim is concerned, the Government has made it clear all along that it is anxious to obtain a resolution of a difficult industrial relations situation in the building industry. The Government also made it quite clear from the beginning that any increase in allowances was not to be a disguised wage increase and that those matters would be taken into account in any submission put by the Government to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. All I can say is that that view will unfold in the course of the proceedings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the Government yet made its views known to the ACTU?
—I am unable to answer that question precisely but, if I may hazard a guess, I very much believe so.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations whether it is a fact that a decision by the Queensland Government to award the tender for construction of dam gates for the Wyvenhoe Dam to a Korean company in preference to local tenderers has now cost the jobs of 25 Brisbane steel workers. Is it within the power of the Commonwealth Government to control or limit the extent to which the jobs of Australian workers are exported in this manner, taking into consideration the consequent loss of taxes and associated benefits to the Australian economy that would accrue if local tenderers were given more favourable treatment?

—It is a fact, as I understand it, that, as Senator Jones pointed out, a Queensland company was unsuccessful in a tender for the dam gates in question and that the work was awarded to a Korean company. It is true that it is within the power of the Commonwealth Government, in the sense that it has the power to control imports, to prevent the letting of a contract to a foreign company in Korea as was done in this case. Of course, however, the exercise of that power, certainly in a random or ad hoc way, would be highly undesirable. It seems to me that two issues are involved. The first is one involving the direct letting of work to overseas firms and the second is the question of the availability or otherwise of overseas technology in the circumstances in which it is introduced into Australia in respect of jobs such as the one Senator Jones referred to. That second matter seems to me to be of much greater importance. It is one, I believe, that the Commonwealth can and should address. The question of the purchasing policies of State governments is, of course, a complex issue. What I find particularly bizarre in the Queensland context is the fact that Queensland operates a very rigorous system of State purchasing preferences as against other States, other Australians and other Australian manufacturing companies. It is all the more regrettable to see a State that does that with such vigour in respect of Australian industry at large pursuing an equally vigorous policy of letting government contracts overseas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, concerns comment made about the likelihood of nuclear attack on the North West Cape, Pine Gap and Nurrungar bases by Dr Desmond Ball in a book published earlier this year and entitled Civil Defence and Australia's Security in the Nuclear Age. I ask the Minister: Is the Government aware that, according to sources quoted in Dr Ball's article in that book entitled 'Limiting Damage from Nuclear Attack', clear and fully documented evidence is given that the United States Government regards the bases in Australia as early and virtually inevitable targets in the case of nuclear war? I ask whether the Minister knows that Dr Ball said, for instance:

QUESTION.PARA: The American missile launching submarines are undoubtedly the least vulnerable.
That is, of course, in comparison with Soviet vessels. Dr Ball continued:

The Soviets could be confident of destroying only a very few of these submarines , even in all-out search and destroy mission. On the other hand they could relatively easily immobilise the whole American sea based force by destroying its communications.

Does the Minister know that Admiral R. Y. Kaufman, United States Navy, testified 'We have to assume an attack will be made on our communications systems' and that the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Communications Command, Control and Intelligence, Dr Gerald Dineen, testified that 'these stations are vulnerable. They are soft targets'? Will the Government make an early informed statement to Australia on these important matters instead of the mishmash of indecision and imprecision we have got so far in answer to this type of question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Returning at the outset to the implied compliment in Senator Mason's question, for any Australian Democrat to refer to anyone else as being engaged in a mish-mash of indecision and imprecision is really to demonstrate chutzpah of academy award dimensions. Senator Mason may recall-I am not sure whether he was here or whether he reads Hansard-that I answered a very similar question on this subject from Senator Chipp on 21 September. I referred then to a statement made by Mr Hayden as Minister for Foreign Affairs on 15 September, in which he said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the contribution made by the joint defence facilities to the deterrence of nuclear war fully justifies any risk that might be seen as arising from our having those facilities in Australia.

Whether Senator Mason or anyone else likes that, it is at least a clear and unequivocal statement of the Government's position. I remind the honourable senator of the Government's assessment, which I again reported in that answer to Senator Chipp's question, that a nuclear war is in fact unlikely. The threat of nuclear attack is believed to be a powerful restraint on the super-powers; to state so much is obvious. I have not studied, nor to my knowledge has the Minister, the article referred to by the honourable senator and I am not in a position to comment on the sources he cites. One can doubt that in an area such as this, where there is considerable room for argument among various experts, definitive predictions can be made about the targeting practices of the super- powers and the degree of risk attaching to those joint facilities in particular circumstances. However, if the honourable senator wishes to place on the Notice Paper his question relating to specific remarks by identified United States officials, I will seek an answer for him from the Minister for Defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Can I take it from the Minister's response that in the event of a nuclear war the Government would regard the early destruction of those three bases as an acceptable risk for this country?

—Senator Mason demonstrates a congenital incapacity to listen to answers clearly given to him. I believe that if he has an opportunity to read the Hansard-there is not much point in my repeating the answer-and has a question he wants to put on notice or to ask me in this chamber, I will be only too delighted to assist him.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I have received a number of queries about the possibility of class actions in Australian law. Can the Attorney-General advise whether it is the Government's intention to introduce legislation in this Parliament enabling class actions to be instituted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's position on class actions is as was stated before the election in the law and justice policy. It was that we would wait essentially on the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission-which is now, I advise the Senate, anticipated some time early to mid-1984-before reaching any kind of definitive conclusion on this. The situation is that at present unless a sufficient private financial interest can be shown an individual has no right to bring a claim in the public interest to restrain damage to the environment or infringement of so-called public rights.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government will certainly be looking at the report and recommendations of the Law Reform Commission, which is addressed to this whole question, with a view to developing proposals for wider access to courts and tribunals within Commonwealth jurisdiction to enable representative individuals and organisations to argue cases of this kind, and will also, coming closer to the concept of class actions as traditionally understood, certainly be exploring means of ensuring redress for multiple small claimants in the consumer, civil rights, discrimination, welfare and environment fields and matters of that kind, although not necessarily at all along the lines of a root and branch acceptance of the concept of class actions as they developed in the United States. I indicate that, while we are waiting for that fuller review of this issue, in the light of the Law Reform Commission report we are nonetheless concerned to ensure in the legislation we are enacting that proper provision is made for representative actions in appropriate cases.

I remind the Senate that one of the provisions in the Sex Discrimination Bill, clause 62, makes provision for a form of representative action in relation to complaints brought under that particular Bill, although a further amendment that is proposed to that will ensure that a complaint brought on a representative or class basis does not give rise to a determination so far as damages are concerned against any putative defendant. The best I can say to the honourable senator is that the matter is under active and continuing review. We will come to a focus of decision on that in the context of the Law Reform Commission report next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs concerns the Government's announced intention to fund schools on a basis of need . I note that while many government schools operate at below average resource standards, many others operate above such standards, a proposition which is self -evident. I ask the Minister: How does the Government intend to apply a needs based policy in the distribution of Commonwealth funds between government school and government school in the States on the basis of relative need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's intention to fund State government schools in a way that will start to overcome some of the gaps between the lower resource government schools and the better off government schools is evidenced in the Budget guidelines. If Senator Baume addresses himself, for example, to capital funding, he will find that $20m has been earmarked for the upgrading and refurbishment of rundown government schools. That decision recognises that some government schools are operating below standard. Similarly, the disadvantaged schools program is directed to government schools which are below standard. Also , the new participation and equity program will bring about reform of secondary schooling to improve participation rates. The details of the implementation of that program are currently being worked out in consultation with State governments, parent organisations, teacher organisations and technical and further education authorities. Priority will be given to those areas and, in the context of this answer, to those government schools which have particularly low participation rates.

ANSWER.PARA: All of those steps demonstrate that we are aware that some government schools are operating below standard. We are taking those steps appropriate for the Commonwealth to take, it not having the basic responsibility for schools but having the responsibility to ensure that standards are raised and that disadvantages are overcome. We will take such steps as funds permit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Ryan' s answer did not address the question-I should have made it clearer-of general recurrent funding of government schools. Would she care to address herself to that part of funding and perhaps in her answer illustrate how in the Australian Capital Territory, for which she has direct responsibility, she might apply the needs based formula as between government school and government school in terms of recurrent funding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to recurrent funding, I am sure Senator Baume is aware that it is the intention of our Government to pursue with State governments negotiations concerning desirable resource standards for all schools and to establish with State governments the relative responsibilities of the Commonwealth and the States in the pursuit of those resource standard targets. This is a new approach to the funding of government schools which is designed to ensure that all government schools reach desirable standards and that Commonwealth funds particularly are directed by the States to the schools most in need of them. It will be a very complex process. Negotiations are only just beginning, and will probably take some time to complete. The end result, when the Commonwealth and State governments have agreed on resource standard targets, will be that the Commonwealth will be in a position to fund much more specifically those programs which will raise the current resource standards of needy government schools.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that the Federal Government has responsibility for schools in the Australian Capital Territory, although a considerable part of that responsibility has been delegated to the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. Since the provision of education in the Australian Capital Territory is generally high, we would not find in the Territory the large discrepancies in resource standards that are found in States such as New South Wales, where the honourable senator comes from, and where in the inner city region or working class areas in the western suburbs of Sydney there are very clear disadvantages as compared with schools in the middle class communities that have long had the support of affluent communities. We simply do not find discrepancies of that kind in the Australian Capital Territory, although it is true that some of our older schools and those schools serving communities that are not quite as well off as others in Canberra have been able to participate in the disadvantaged schools program and special programs, such as English as a second language, which recognise that some schools take a higher proportion of migrant children than do other schools. The senator has really asked me to use the example of Australian Capital Territory schools to describe how we will set about some sort of needs approach to recurrent funding for government schools, but it is not a very good example because the gaps are not as great as they are in the senator's own State. I think I have given the answer in respect of our negotiations with State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. I refer the Minister to the most recent indicators of building activity which indicate a significant upturn in the housing market particularly since the announcement of the Government's new housing package in May. Does the Minister agree that these figures show a massive acceptance by home buyers and prospective home buyers of the Government's new housing initiatives? Can we anticipate a lowering of unemployment in the building trades as a result of this renewed activity, particularly in view of the latest drop in interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I believe that not only the Government but also the housing industry in general anticipate a reduction in unemployment in this industry as a result of increasing activity. I am reminded that prior to the present Government coming to power, housing commencements had reached the lowest level for some 20 years in Australia. Funds for public housing to the States had been drastically cut, and we had about 100,000 people on public housing waiting lists as well as very long waiting lists in some areas for private rental accommodation. Since that time we have had an upturn, I am informed by the Department, of dwelling commencements, which went from 105,000 in 1982-83, which was 20 per cent down on those for 1981-82 and was the lowest for any financial year since 1962-63. Dwelling commencements increased by 5 per cent in the March quarter of 1983 from those in the very low December quarter of 1982, and by 13 per cent in the June quarter. Dwelling approvals and market information suggest that the recovery is being maintained. Similarly, lending for housing has shown strong recovery from the very low levels of that year. Lending by the banks and permanent building societies, seasonally adjusted, increased by 4 per cent in the three months to July 1983 compared with that for the three months to April, and by 30 per cent compared with that for the three months to July 1982. The high level of lending has increased and will increase as interest rates come down.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that all these factors, plus the way in which the first home owners program was welcomed by the building industry in general and by the real estate industry in general, indicate that there are very good grounds to believe that the present upturn will continue and will probably increase. That is good news not only for the building industry but also for those industries whose job prospects come as a spin-off from increased building activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. In a recent interview published in the Australian Pensioner, did the Minister say that under the Government's Medicare arrangements there would be no need to have a pensioner health benefits card? Can the Minister assure all pensioners that they will have the same benefits for health care under Medicare as they now enjoy under the pensioner health benefits card?

—I thank Senator Messner for the question. No, I did not say that. That answer came up in a discussion about the lesser need for the pensioner health benefits card with Medicare providing basic hospital and medical cover. There will still be a necessity for the presence of the pensioner health benefits card, if for no other reason than that of the pharmaceutical benefits that are attached to that card. At the same time, I am aware that the State governments, some local governments and some private organisations use eligibility for the pensioner health benefits card as a cut-off point for the provision of their own fringe benefits. Whether that should persist or whether it is a satisfactory situation is something that we should resolve between the Federal Government, the State governments and local governments. But in the meantime, the card will be issued. I am sorry if the impression was gained from that interview that that would not be so.

—Has the Minister for Veterans' Affairs heard the report on this morning's Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio news regarding the announcement by the British Defence Ministry of a study into the health of British personnel involved in nuclear weapons tests in Australia and the Pacific in the 1950s? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether any action will be initiated by the Australian Government to examine possible increased cancer risks amongst Australian personnel involved in those tests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since coming to office the Government has received a number of representations on this matter from serving personnel. Service personnel who were involved in the atomic testings in Australia have written to me and I understand that some of my ministerial colleagues have also had representations made to them. As a result of these representations I have initiated investigations into the matter. It appears that during the period in question, from 1952 to 1958, some 21 nuclear tests were conducted in various parts of Australia; for example, at the Monte Bello Islands off Western Australia, at Emu Field and Maralinga in South Australia and at Christmas Island in the South Pacific.

ANSWER.PARA: It appears that some 8,000 serving personnel and 8,000 civilians, as well as an unspecificied number of Aborigines, were in the relevant parts of Australia during the actual testing period, although the vast majority of these persons were not actually present during the testing of the atomic weapons. Consequently the Government's view in the past has been that most of these people experienced a minimal risk of exposure. However, the actual question of whether persons in the vicinity during the tests were exposed to unacceptable levels of radiation is of some concern to the Government. We are dissatisfied with the attitude taken by the previous Government in this matter. However, the diversity of evidence available makes it rather difficult to reach conclusions at this stage. It will require much careful and detailed analysis before any initiatives can be taken.

I do note that the news report this morning refers to a British university study which claims a disproportionate incidence of leukemia amongst servicemen who took part in the tests. That study, which was conducted by Birmingham University, found that among 330 British serving personnel who were present at the tests the incidence of leukemia was about 60 per cent above the average. There is also considerable concern in the United States of America surrounding recently discovered documents which suggest that radiation safety provisions for Navy personnel present at atomic tests at Bikini Atoll in 1946 were less stringent than they could have been. In conclusion, I can only assure Senator Bolkus that the Government has taken positive steps to determine whether there is a link between cancer risk and the presence of personnel at the test sites. A number of studies have been commissioned, the results of which should be publicly available before the end of this year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer to an advertisement for Telecom Australia mobile phones which says, in part:

QUESTION.PARA: Of course, you'll be saving time not having to hunt for Public Phones . . .

I ask: Is this advertisement an admission by Telecom that the number of public phones throughout this country is much too low, so much so that one has actually to hunt to find one? Will the Minister ask Telecom Australia to examine the possibility of installing more public phones, particularly in remote areas, now that it has had time to analyse the increased income from such phones due to the present 20c fee?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not have thought that an advertisement by Telecom advertising mobile phones in cars, containing words like 'you will save time by not having to hunt for a public telephone', would be intended by Telecom to advertise an inadequacy in the number of public phone boxes. However, I concede that that is a question of interpretation and my interpretation might well be different from that of Senator Townley. I have no idea whether that advertisement can be construed as such an admission. I will ask Telecom, through the Minister, to examine and advise me on the matters raised in the honourable senator's question.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister read Press reports that the Federal Council of the Liberal Party has carried a motion supporting means testing of welfare payments? Can the Minister explain to Opposition senators the merits of the Federal Liberal Party policy?
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. This has nothing whatsoever to do with Government policy. It deals with Opposition policy and surely is out of order.
—Speaking to the point of order, as Federal Liberal Party policy is now coming into line with Government policy, I think it is quite in order to point out the similarities.
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to reframe his question and bring it into line with the Standing Orders.
—I ask the Minister for Social Security to list the approach to social welfare that the current Government has and to compare it with the approaches of other people in the community.

—I think Senator Robert Ray's question is a pertinent one in view of the fact that there is some debate in the community at the moment about the approaches of the Government and the alternative government-the Opposition-to welfare payments in this community. Quite clearly, the Government believes that there should be a mixture of universal benefits like family allowances and selective benefits like pensions. Where we have selectivity we believe that there should be a means test which is equitable, and therefore it should incorporate not only income but also assets. I note that on the weekend, by coincidence, the Federal Council of the Liberal Party passed a motion saying that it believes in a needs based welfare system and that it therefore believes that benefits should be paid out on the basis of needs, and any equitable basis of needs again should incorporate assets as well as income.
—Would that be binding on Senator Walters?

—This would not be binding on Senator Walters or anyone else, but of course it flies a bit in the face of some of the statements made by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, who has announced that if his party came to power it would repeal any legislation by the present Government to introduce an assets test. Of course, in a subsequent interview he said that that did not mean he was opposed to an assets test and that it did not mean that the Liberal Party, when it came to power, would not introduce an assets test; it would just repeal the Australian Labor Party's assets test and introduce its own. This was complicated even more on the weekend by the announcement by Mr Peacock that he opposed very strongly the fact that any antiques in the home may be excluded from the assets test. In other words, he wanted the things that he defined as antiques included. Mr Peacock wants the inspectors and the valuers to go into each person's home and to value everything, including all antiques; to really complicate the assets test and interfere with the privacy of the individual. What Mr Peacock is advocating, of course, is that a woman who has a dresser or an item of furniture which was given to her 30 or 40 years before--

—I rise on a point of order. Mr President, you sought a rephrasing of the question to accord with the Standing Orders. That was done. The early part of the answer was also in accordance with the Standing Orders but the Minister is now canvassing what he purports to put as Opposition policy. However, it is not Opposition policy. Since what he is saying is inaccurate as well as outside the Standing Orders, I take a point of order.
—There is no point of order.

—If Mr Peacock is the example that Senator Chaney does not like, perhaps we will make a comparison with the behaviour of Senator Chaney when he was the Minister for Social Security. Senator Chaney frequently made the comment , as did members of his Party, that in fact welfare payments such as pensions should be distributed on a basis of need. Some two years ago he made a Budget announcement that one of the problems was that people in an artificial way were circumventing the income test that his Government had introduced. He announced in the Budget that in fact the Government was going to do something about it. I remember Senator Chaney saying: 'We will limit people to perhaps having $3,000 in an interest free cheque account'. After some months of questioning by me, Senator Giles and others, we found that the Liberal-Country Party Government at the time gave up and would not do anything. It would not do anything, not because it had changed its mind about what it believed should be done, but because its Prime Minister wanted to have an election and it would not do anything unpopular at that time. The vast majority of people in this country, no matter what their political beliefs, believe we should have a needs based social security system and that that system should be based on people's true assets and true income and not just on income alone with the amount of circumvention that we have had. I am glad that the Federal Council of the Liberal Party moved a motion of that type but I have no faith in Liberal Party politicians following that motion through into action should they ever come into government.

—I wish to ask a question about the current airline pilots strike. However, I am having great difficulty in focusing on the appropriate Minister to whom to put my question. I would hope that a number of Ministers-the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, the Minister for Aviation, the Minister for Transport and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations- would be concerned.
—Order! Would the honourable senator address his question to a Minister?

—I conclude that I should address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. What action does this Government intend to take to prevent the airline pilots of two of Australia's most highly protected corporations from taking unnecessary and provocative strike action simply to publicise the point of view of this privileged minority group? Is the Government willing to allow the potential of the Australian tourist industry to be destroyed as a result of the increased reputation for unreliability, the increases in fares which inevitably follow such strikes and the inevitable further decline of air travel in Australia? Can the Government take positive steps to protect the people who use our monopolistic airline system and who become the innocent victims of individuals who lack any compassion in their irresponsible behaviour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans's question contains a number of elements. I would first of all make the point that the Government has on numerous occasions had discussions with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and has, in the view of the Government, met the legitimate concerns of the air pilots. But even more recently, the Government has offered to meet and discuss the specific application of the new arrangements relating to taxing of lump sum superannuation payments in the aviation industry. However, the Government will not meet and discuss the application of the superannuation arrangements with a privileged group like the air pilots while they are on strike. The Government will not concede to the sort of industrial blackmail which the air pilots are engaging in.
—That is what you said to the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association and you complained. I am glad to hear that. That is a very good statement of principle.

—Mr President, I was interrupted by the Leader of the Opposition. The Government will proceed to have further discussions with the air pilots in relation to matters of detail only in terms of specific application but not while they are engaging in industrial action. Senator Evans asks what action the Government might take if this situation continues; that is to say, if the present industrial action is renewed or prolonged in any way. The precise details of any action that the Government will take will be determined at the time in relation to the particular circumstances which exist at that time. If it is necessary, the Government will take the most stringent action because the air pilots are risking not only their own conditions of employment but also the conditions of employment of other aviation employees, many of whom also enjoy a wellprotected status in the community.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator is quite right to say that the actions of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots will result in significant damage to both Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia, neither airline being in a position to afford that damage at this point. I add that the Government has very strong doubts about whether the Federation of Air Pilots is communicating with its members to the extent that it might the degree of discussions which the Government has had with the Federation and the precise nature of those discussions. We believe that that lack of communication is being reflected on an increasing basis from day to day throughout the rank and file of the air pilots in both the airlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security: Why has it been necessary to give an immediate warning against the deprivation of assets when the assets test is not to apply for another 12 months?

—As I have said in previous answers to Senator Sir John Carrick and others in this place, in warning that artificial deprivation of assets will not be counted in calculating the assets test the Government is carrying out what is a normal and reasonable action in this area. Without this, people would have the capacity to deprive themselves artificially of assets-to hand over assets to relatives or others, who could then provide them with an income from those assets, thus getting around not only the income test but also the assets test. However, normal expenditure-expenditure which provides a return for the expenditure of cash-normal gifts to relatives, et cetera, will, as before, not be considered as deprivation. The Government, through the Department of Social Security and, I understand, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, will look only at blatant cases of deprivation to circumvent the tests artificially.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON AUSTRALIA'S SECURITY AND INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to statements which have been made by counsel for the Commonwealth in his closing address to the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies, particularly those concerning the credibility of Mr Combe and the degree of culpability of Mr Young. To what extent were these statements made on the instructions of the Government?

—I do not propose to canvass, in any more detail than I have done since the whole Hope Royal Commission started, questions as to the conduct of the Commission or what was discussed before it or submitted to it, except to say that, as with the conduct of the case generally, counsel have been in discussion obviously with the relevant Government Ministers. There has been general discussion about the nature of the submissions that are to be put and the way in which the case is to be conducted. There are many matters of detail that have been left to counsel's discretion along the way. Short of going into the precise details of the particular matters raised in the course of a long two -day address which Senator Crichton-Browne has in mind and which I do not propose to do, it is impossible to give any more precise an answer than that.

—I ask a supplementary question. Is the Attorney-General saying that, whether of either a specific or a general nature, the two matters I raised by way of question were not canvassed between the Government and its Queen's Counsel?

—There is very little I can add. Questions going to the credibility of Mr Combe are obviously at the heart of the Commission and extend over very many individual matters that are before the Commission for determination and decision. Clearly, many of those matters have been the subject of detailed discussion; other aspects have simply been the subject of general communication. Similarly, the matters involving Mr Young involve a wide range of considerations. My answer, as originally given, stands.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's decision granting a 4.3 per cent wage rise to all workers, provided the unions agreed not to press further sectional wage claims. I ask the Minister: What are the parts of the current building industry pay deal that the Government opposes on the ground that they breach the new wage guidelines? Will the Government's objections be raised by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations when he meets with representatives of the building unions this week?

—The national wage case decision was in accordance with the Government's wishes in the sense that the Government made a submission on these matters to the national wage Bench, which was accepted, and it provides the restraint in relation to sectional claims to which Senator Walters referred. The honourable senator asked: What are the portions of the current building industry agreement under discussion with which the Government disagrees? As I have already answered a question on this matter at Question Time today, I repeat that the Government indicated right from the beginning of this claim that it would not agree with any wage increases which were disguised as allowances. In the course of the proceedings before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission this week, the Government will be putting its position in relation to that matter. Senator Walters asked me whether Mr Willis will explain that view to the representatives of the building industry unions when he meets them this week. I can only say to the honourable senator that I assume so, because I think he is meeting them to tell them that. If he does not explain that to them this week I would regard that as an extraordinary circumstance indeed and a very strange meeting.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am not quite sure whether the Minister said that the Government considers that those allowances are part of the wage structure. He answered the question very broadly and not specifically, as I had asked, in relation to the builders labourers.

—With respect, that is a comment rather than a supplementary question. This matter is currently before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I am not going to go through all the elements of the so-called building industry package and identify in the Senate which matters are regarded as legitimate allowances and which matters are regarded as perhaps a wage increase. What I am saying is that the Government will put its view in the course of the proceedings before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which is the appropriate place in which to do it.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, concerns the report of the Fry Committee of Inquiry into the Recognition of Overseas Qualifications. I ask: When is it envisaged that that part of the Fry Committee report recommending registration of foreign dentists in Australia will be implemented?

—I am afraid that I do not have that answer for Senator Bolkus today. I had it for him last week and I have mislaid it today. I will refer the matter to the Minister and obtain an answer as soon as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment.
