DEBATE.TITLE: SALARIES AND WAGES PAUSE ACT REPEAL BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to repeal the Salaries and Wages Pause Act 1982. The Act which took effect on 23 December 1982 suspended the power of various remuneration fixing authorities to make or vary awards or determinations in relation to the remuneration and conditions of employment of Commonwealth employees for twelve months.
The Act has also prevented the Remuneration Tribunal and the Academic Salaries Tribunal from holding inquiries or making determinations or reports.

Further it has maintained the level of remuneration paid to pharmacists for the dispensing of certain prescriptions and has influenced the income of members of the medical profession by maintaining the level of fees approved for payment of benefits from registered health insurance funds.

This action in the public sector was taken by the previous Government prior to its approach to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a general wages freeze in both the public and private sectors.

Such moves resulted from the clear disarray in which they found themselves following the wages explosion of 1982. That wages explosion was due in large part to the policies of the previous Government, especially their successful efforts to undermine the centralised wage fixing system which had existed since 1975.

Following the destruction of wage indexation, the former Government found itself bereft of any workable wages policy. The encouragement of market-based negotiations on an industry basis clearly had disastrous results. Consequently they returned to a highly centralised solution in the form of a wages freeze, which depended for its effectiveness on continued high levels of unemployment.

After hearing submissions from the parties, led by the Federal Government, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission decided on 23 December last year to introduce a wage pause for 6 months until June 1983 when it would review the situation.

At that stage, it was decided by the Commission that its wages pause guidelines would remain in place pending determination of a National Wage claim lodged by the ACTU. Submissions in the National Wage case have now been completed and the Commission has reserved its decision.

The Government submitted strongly to the Commission in that case that now was an appropriate time to end the wages pause and to introduce a system of centralised wage fixing based on full, six-monthly, cost of living adjustments.

Such a system, the Government argued, is fully suited to the needs of our times and is clearly in the best longer term interests of Australia. It protects the real incomes of wage and salary earners and provides for real increases over time, thus satisfying the basic demands of the unions for an equitable wages policy.
It will also enable us to develop a new era in industrial relations, with an end to the bitterness which inevitably results from a decentralised, confrontationist approach.

But, most importantly, it is a wages policy which, in conjunction with the broad thrust of other Government policies, is conducive to a sustained economic recovery with greater job opportunities, reduced inflation, greater international competitiveness and improved business profitability.

The Government is of the strong belief that, although the economy is only now beginning to emerge from the deepest recession for 50 years, it is the appropriate time to break the wages freeze and establish such a new wage determination system.
To attempt to extend the freeze any longer would be a grave mistake.

As the economy recovers, during 1983 and beyond, the capacity and determination of an increasing segment of the workforce to seek and obtain wage increases will inevitably increase. Sectional claims would become more and more common, with every prospect of a new wages explosion occurring.

Thus any effort to extend the wage freeze during a period of economic recovery would, in all likelihood, catapult the economy right back to where we were before the wage freeze-with wages out of control and rising incompatibly with inflation reduction or sustained economic recovery.

Now is the time, therefore, before economic recovery takes off, for a new system of wage determination to be introduced. Although such a system will involve a wage increase at this stage, it will be to the long term benefit to the nation as a whole if it introduces a national policy which is accepted and adhered to by the unions.

As the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the National Wage Case is imminent the Government has decided that the Salaries and Wages Pause Act should be repealed so that Commonwealth employees will once again be subject to decisions of appropriate arbitral tribunals. To do nothing could result in a situation where Commonwealth employees are unfairly treated vis-a- vis State Government employees and the private sector.

Repeal of the Act is necessary to ensure that the wage fixation principles determined by the National Wage decision can be applied throughout Commonwealth employment without undue delay. Without prompt action obvious anomalies and inequities will occur which could result in unnecessary industrial problems.
Commonwealth employees will thus be treated on the same basis as other wage and salary earners who will be subject to the application of that decision.

The Government's industrial relations co-ordination machinery will be used to ensure that Commonwealth employing authorities observe the spirit of the decisions of tribunals in respect of employees not covered by awards or determinations. We will, of course, argue for a consistent application of the Commission's wage fixing principles before those other special tribunals whose powers are restored by the repeal of the Act.

To facilitate hearing of the National Wage Case whilst the Act was in place, a regulation under section 10 (2) of the Act has been made to restore power to the Public Service Arbitrator and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in respect to two specific determinations so that the technical opportunity was created for claims covering Commonwealth employees to be referred to the National Wage Full Bench.

The Act also had the effect of keeping in operation regulations made under s. 4 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 which would otherwise have automatically ceased to be in force after the period of 12 months and 15 sitting days of the House of Representatives. These regulations set out the professional services in respect of which Commonwealth medical benefits are payable and the appropriate fee for Commonwealth medical benefits purposes, in accordance with which such benefits are determined.

The present Bill, while repealing the Salaries and Wages Pause Act, would provide for the continued operation of these regulations for a maximum period of 9 months from the date of commencement of the Repeal Act. This would allow adequate time for any inquiry to be held to determine whether new fees for medical benefits purposes are necessary and for the preparation of new regulations prescribing any such fees.

The Act also prohibited the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal from holding any inquiries for 12 months. That Tribunal is a body set up under the National Health Act to determine the manner in which the Commonwealth prices of pharmaceutical benefits are to be ascertained for the purpose of payments to pharmacists.

S.98BA (4) of the National Health Act requiries the Tribunal to issue a report of its findings within 12 months of the date of its last report. When the Salaries and Wages Pause Act came into force the Tribunal had commenced hearings for its fourth inquiry and this inquiry was forthwith suspended. The last determination made by the Tribunal was in June 1982 in respect of the third inquiry.
With the repeal of the Act the prohibition on the Tribunal's operations will be lifted and it will be free to complete that fourth inquiry or commence a new inquiry.

Clause 4 (2) of this Bill provides that a mandatory requirement for the Tribunal to issue a report every 12 months will not apply in respect of the first report after the repeal of the Salaries and Wages Pause Act. The Bill will allow a further 6 months for the Tribunal to issue its next report. After this, the arrangements will revert to those that are provided for in s. 98BA (4) of the National Health Act.

Finally may I say that the Government is presenting this Bill of Repeal now so that it will be possible, following passage, to seek Royal Assent as close as is practicable to the date of the National Wage decision which would then be permitted to apply equally to all in the public sector as well as those in the private sector. If, contrary to our expectations, the Commission decides not to award a wage rise at this time, Australian Government employees will, by passage of this Bill, be in no more advantageous position than employees in the private sector.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The purpose of the Bill is to permit increases in Overseas Student Charges which the Government announced in the 1983-84 Budget. Honourable Senators will recall that when the Overseas Students Charge Act was enacted in 1979, the maximum rate of charge was fixed by Parliament at $2,500 for a year in respect of the enrolment of an overseas student in a prescribed course. This maximum level has remained unchanged for the last three years. The rates set in 1979 represented about 40 per cent of the average cost of higher education.

To reflect changes in the cost of tertiary education, the Government has decided that the charge will, from the beginning of 1984, be increased by approximately 15 per cent-from a minimum of $2,150 to a maximum of $2,900 a year . The new rate of charge will represent about only one third of the estimated average cost of tertiary education in 1983.

It is to be noted that unlike parents of Australian tertiary students, overseas students and their parents do not contribute significantly to the cost of tertiary education in Australia through the taxation system. The charge on overseas students is therefore required to defray part of the cost of their education.

The Treasurer has stated in the Budget that the estimated total number of students liable for the charge-excluding those whose liability is met by the Australian Government-was about 8,300 in 1982-83, yielding $16.2m of the total revenue of $19m. The number is expected to rise to about 11,300 in 1983-84 and account for $25.6m of the total revenue of $29.2m in that year, the balance being attributable to Government sponsored students. The Government will continue to meet the charge for private students from Papua New Guinea and other developing countries in the South Pacific Region, and also for students sponsored by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. This assistance is part of Australia's aid program for this region.

In the past few years, particularly in 1983, the numbers of overseas students admitted to Australia increased substantially over those of the previous year. The Government is concerned that as a result Australian students may not have been able to obtain places in the course of their choice at tertiary institutions.

On the basis of advice from the Department of Education and Youth Affairs, the Government has decided that the number of private overseas students entering tertiary institutions in Australia in 1984 should be limited to approximately 4, 000. This is still an increase of 400 over 1983. Included are 2,500 overseas students who are now completing their secondary education in Australia. This means that the Government must limit the number of overseas students directly entering tertiary institutions in 1984 to 1,500. Further, we have decided that the number of new secondary students to enter Australia will be limited to 2,000 . Thus, the total entry for 1984 will be approximately 3,500 new students-that is, 2,000 into secondary institutions and 1,500 into tertiary institutions.

I might refer to the lack of control exhibited by the former Government which has created the necessity to now curtail new entry to both secondary and tertiary institutions even though the total entering tertiary institutions will be increased by 400. For instance, total secondary new intakes from Malaysia surged from 1,100 in 1981 to 2,580 in 1983.

If we are to control future intakes into tertiary institutions it necessarily follows that we must now control secondary school intakes. Thus, the Malaysians have been restricted to approximately 1,050 new secondary students for 1984, a big reduction on 1983, but nevertheless equivalent to the 1981 total.

Similarly, a total of 1,650 new secondary and tertiary students were admitted in 1981 from Malaysia. This rose to 3,200 in 1983. It will be approximately 1, 640 in 1984, again close to the 1981 figure. I mentioned these facts to show that if secondary school intakes are allowed to increase dramatically over several years, we can expect pressure to reduce new tertiary entry figures so that the total intake of private overseas students to tertiary institutions is commensurate with our ability to absorb them. Any criticism of our need to reduce moderately new entries from overseas should be directed squarely at the previous Government.

The Government has decided to conduct a review of the Private Overseas Student Program bearing in mind the large demand for places in Australian educational institutions, some existing inequities, and difficulties in the administration of the existing program.

The Government has appointed a Committee under the Chairmanship of Professor John Goldring, Professor of Law at Macquarie University. The Committee of Review has been asked to recommend changes to the Private Overseas Student Program which will achieve Government objectives-that is, to encourage private overseas students to study in Australia without reducing opportunities for Australian residents and without dramatically increasing public sector outlays.

This is a complex and important task for the Committee. Many aspects of the current private overseas student policy and procedures will need to be critically examined, including the proportion of costs of training to be borne by the student, whether priority should be given to students from particular countries, and the basis of future selection methods.
The Review Committee has already called for submissions from interested Governments, organisations and individuals. It is hopeful of the widest possible consultations and participation in the review.

Mr President, the Bill substitutes the new maximum level of charge of $2,900 for the current maximum rate of $2,500 in section 6 of the Principal Act. The actual fees payable will be specified by Regulation as in the past.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Mr Deputy President, these Regulations were referred to the Standing Committee on 24 August last for investigation and report. It was clear that there was considerable concern amongst members of those industries affected by the new prescribed payments system of taxation, which I will refer to as the PPS, that the introduction of the system would involve a marked increase in paperwork and administrative costs. As the Committee had to report to the Senate on the reference within a very short time, the Committee had to abbreviate its consideration.

We thank those who made submissions for preparing and delivering them to the Committee expeditiously and for the fact that the submissions were generally succinct. The Committee held a one-day public hearing on 7 September during which the Committee heard evidence from the Commissioner of Taxation and a number of the organisations which had made submissions to the Committee. During the hearing the Committee was able to discuss with officers of the Australian Taxation Office those problems raised by other witnesses during their evidence. This proved a valuable means of clarifying confusing aspects of the PPS and, we believe, allowed the Taxation Office to consider sensible changes to the system to simplify paperwork and administrative requirements. A feature of all submissions and evidence was the general expression of support for moves to eliminate tax evasion in the industries which are covered by the Regulations. Equally, however, all the industries expressed reservations about the system and complained of the difficulties anticipated by their members in complying with the PPS requirements.

The Senate might note that the statistics provided to the Committee by the Australian Taxation Office, which are published on page 8 of the report, show a very large number of applications for new file numbers with the Taxation Office. In the short period from mid-August to 19 September, more than 16,000 new file numbers had been issued. It was illuminating to learn that a large numer of applicants apparently informed taxation officers that they had only recently arrived in Australia from New Zealand.

The PPS introduces a new form of taxation collection to Australia and an entirely new set of administrative requirements which are to be complied with by taxpayers. These relate not only to compliance with PPS but to those who have sought exemption from making payments under the system or variation of the sum they are obliged to pay. The Committee has diuscussed the requirements in some detail in its report and has made recommendations which, if accepted, should reduce the paperwork required of both payers and payees under the system. Firstly, the Committee recommends that the Income Tax Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rules 1983 No. 111 made under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 not be disallowed but that the Committee continue to examine the practical operation of the prescribed payments system of taxation which came into effect on 1 September 1983 and that the Committee report its findings and conclusions to the Senate on or before the first sitting day of the Senate in September 1984. Secondly, we recommend that the Government give early consideration to amending the Income Tax Assessment Act in the ways set out in the Committee's second recommendation on page 1 of the report. These amendments, relating to exemption declarations and deduction forms, would simplify the operation of the PPS and reduce the volume of paper and administration involved in it.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALARIES AND WAGES PAUSE ACT REPEAL BILL 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating two Bills. I understand that the Government wishes to deal on a cognate basis with the Salaries and Wages Pause Act Repeal Bill 1983 and the Public Service Amendment Act 1983. Is that correct?
—Yes.

—And, I think also the statement put down by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, about the expenditure of wages pause moneys under the previous Government's program. The Bills are not Bills which are being opposed by the Opposition. With respect to the statement which has been put down relating to the wage pause expenditure, I merely wish to record the Opposition's regret that there has been rather ineffective use of the moneys which were made available to create employment, moneys which were made available to the States by the Commonwealth Government in the face of a very difficult employment situation and very high levels of unemployment. It would appear that except for the money which was made available for welfare housing the States had great difficulty in utilising the money quickly. I suppose that we must all draw lessons from that with respect to any future need to have moneys expended in this manner.

SPEECH.PARA: To turn to the legislation, we have before us legislation which is not opposed by the Opposition but which is, nonetheless, very significant. The Opposition welcomes the opportunity to debate the issues which are raised by it. The Salaries and Wages Pause Act Repeal Bill, which is the main Bill we are debating this afternoon, is a Bill which represents the last stage of dismantling the wage pause which was put in place by the Fraser Government. The bulk of that dismantling has already been done. Non-public sector wages have been freed up by the decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission issued less than two weeks ago, a decision which was made by the Commission at the urging of the Hawke Government. The Commission provided, at the request of the Government and with the urging of the trade union movement and over and above the objections of the employers, a 4.3 per cent rise in wages to take into account changes in the consumer prices index for the March and June quarters. That wage increase, which will flow through to non-public sector wages, was, of course, not accessible to the public sector because of the Salaries and Wages Pause Act which the Fraser Government passed and which provided for a 12-months wage pause for public sector employees. This legislation will repeal that wage pause for the public sector and will enable it to take the same rise as the private sector.

It is quite clear why we do not oppose the legislation. It was never the intention of the previous Government to freeze solely the wages of public sector employees. We sought and indeed we obtained a generalised wage pause and now that that generalised wage pause has been cast aside by the Hawke Government, we would not wish to oppose the legislation which enables equal treatment to be meted out to the public sector. We take this debate as a very necessary opportunity to mark the depth of our concern at what the Government has done. We are deeply concerned at what the decisions of this Government with respect to the wage pause will do to Australia and what those decisions will do to our already too numerous unemployed. The decision of the Arbitration Commission to grant a general wage increase at this stage, I believe, was greeted with disappointment by all Australians who are concerned about the plight of the unemployed as against the continuing welfare of the employed and their ability to maintain the standard of living that they have achieved. I should like to quote the remarks of Mr Bryan Noakes from the Confederation of Australian Industry. He said, and I endorse what he said:
There is no justification for this decision either in economics or in logic.

It is almost inconceivable that in the midst of a contracting economy, with unemployment and inflation both at double-digit levels, the commission should once again embark on a wage indexation experiment.

To grant a general wage increase of this magnitude in current economic circumstances, and to adopt a system of wage indexation for the future, can only set back recovery, further depress profitability and investment, and further reduce our ability to compete on domestic and overseas markets.

I do not think there is any really serious non-political observer who is denying that those facts put forward by Mr Noakes on behalf of the Confederation of Australian Industry are true. It is the very great concern of the Opposition that what has been done by the Government is in the interests of some Australians, namely, those who are employed and who are seeking to ensure that the increases in their real wages obtained over recent years continue to apply and that it will be to the detriment of those many Australians who are unemployed. It is interesting to compare a reporter's version of a government official's response to the decision. I was struck by a report by Mr Gregory Hywood in the Australian Financial Review of 26 September. He said:

. . . senior Government people are cock-a-hoop about the decision which not only establishes the prices and incomes accord but severely limits the opportunities for recalcitrant unions to operate outside it.
He continued:
'It was as if we wrote it ourselves', a Government official said.
The bottle of vintage Veuve Cliquot on his desk was proof enough that, apart from the occasional hiccup, the Government's wages policy has so far gone as smoothly as could be hoped.

I think there is some marvellous but rather unhappy symbolism in the picture of that bottle of Veuve Cliquot on the official's desk and hope he enjoyed drinking it. It may well be that French champagne was an appropriate response for an official in secure employment. I do not believe that it would be regarded as a very proper response by the 10 to 11 per cent of Australians who are without jobs. The official was welcoming a decision which will, on the Government's own predictions and on the predictions of its officials, confirm higher and rising unemployment. This Bill, the Bill that we will pass here today, simply confirms that public servants, like other Australians in secure employment, will have to sacrifice nothing in the interests of creating jobs for the unemployed.
I return to what Mr Noakes had to say about the effect of the decision of the Arbitration Commission which this legislation will enable to be applied to the Public Service. He said:
The annual cost of this increase to industry is the equivalent of the annual wages bill for more than 200,000 full-time employees.
The increase will make it even more difficult for employers to maintain existing jobs and will act as a severe disincentive to any increase in employment levels.

That is quite simply why the Opposition is concerned by what the Government is doing and why we are concerned that the wages pause has been cast aside. We are not concerned to maintain a differential burden on the part of public servants and that is why we do not oppose this legislation. We are concerned about where the Government purports to be taking Australia and its non-working work force. In fact, I think that the whole of this area and the Government's antics in this area are typical of the Alice in Wonderland air which seems to pervade Australia . We have desperate problems for one in 10 people, we have desperate problems for one in four of our young people. I do not pretend that those problems are the creation of the Hawke Government. Of course they are not. They are very difficult problems which have emerged over the last few years and indeed, I suppose, had their genesis in the middle 1970s. We have very significant difficulties for many in our community and yet we have behaviour by governments and by people in Australia which seems to ignore totally the reality of the disadvantaged. We have just come out of a 10 weeks strike in the Pilbara which erodes our ability to export and has certainly eroded our reputation as a supplier of raw materials. For 10 weeks there was an industrial dispute which certainly damaged Australia in the ways that I have mentioned. That strike has just concluded but the damage has been done. Today well paid pilots are conducting a political strike almost contemporaneously with air fare rises. We find that the Government cannot even get its letters posted. It cannot receive mail or send it because its letters languish in a strikebound post office. All of these things and this breach of the wage pause, this casting aside of the wage pause and this granting of wage rises which will exacerbate the unemployment situation, occur under a government which boasts a special relationship with the trade union movement and which is very proud of its successes in having and forging a special relationship with that trade union movement.

In this piece of legislation that we are considering today we complete the Government's wages policy jigsaw and that jigsaw, when put together, clearly presents a picture in which the better off in the community are advantaged at the cost of the unemployed. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations , Mr Willis, had the gall in his second reading speech to describe the 1982 legislation, which is now being repealed, as 'action against the public sector'. I would describe that use of language by Mr Willis as petty misdescription. The fact is that the wage pause was introduced to help redress the balance in Australia. We are a country out of balance in a number of significant respects. It was a contribution to redressing the balance between wages and profits. I do not think any serious person-I am sure that includes Senator Walsh, who is here representing the Government in this very near empty chamber-would for a moment deny the importance of profit share and the importance of profits to industry in ensuring that there is fresh investment and the creation of employment. I do not think Senator Walsh would deny-he cannot deny what is an unarguable fact-that profit share has slipped.

TALK.START.PARA: —That doesn't mean that I agree with everything you have said, though.

—No, but on that aspect the honourable senator would agree that the profit share has slipped, and that is a bad thing for the prospects of investment and the creation of fresh employment. The wage pause was also aimed at doing something to redress the balance between the employed and the unemployed in Australia. Good heavens, if there is a clear distinction in the circumstances of any groups of Australians it is between the employed and the unemployed. I have heard plenty of protestations from honourable senators supporting the Australian Labor Party, both since it has been in government and while is was in opposition. They have made the point about the difficulties of the unemployed. What did this wage pause do? It did nothing more than take projected increases in wages from people in secure employment and direct that that money should be used to provide alternative employment for people who were currently unemployed. So, when Mr Willis describes what we did as action against the public sector, I accuse him of petty politicking and I say that is was a good, honourable and desirable move on the part of government to redress some of the very real imbalances which exist in our community and which I thought Labor governments were about trying to solve.

SPEECH.PARA: The wage pause was aimed at all wage and salary earners, not just at the public sector. It was the belief of the then Government that all wage and salary earners could make some sacrifice. It started, of course, with holding back our own salaries. I believe that that was a most fitting place to start. It took away from those Australians in employment nothing but the increases they anticipated over the following 12 months. It provided that those moneys would go to provide new jobs for the unemployed. I believe-I think plenty of commentators would confirm this-that that was economically appropriate. I believe that it was idealistic and I believe that it was accepted by the people of Australia. Lastly , Mr Deputy President, I believe that it worked. This Government's throwing aside of something which had all those qualities is very strange politics and in my view very strange leadership.

I address myself to the second last point I made: That the pause which the then Government sought and had the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission impose, and which it also imposed through legislation, was accepted by the people of Australia. If we go back to April, to a stage when quite clearly public opinion was not being carried by any favourable view of the outgoing Fraser Government- we had just suffered a very severe political defeat-we find that surveys of opinion in that month showed that 70 per cent of Australians aged 14 years and over approved of a wage freeze for everyone until the end of this year. So the extraordinary public response to the idea that those in work should make some sacrifice for those who were out of work was that 70 per cent of Australians aged 14 years and over went along with it. More recently, after a longer period of the Hawke Government, we find in a public opinion poll published last week that 47 per cent of Australians said that we should not increase wages at all this year. Nearly half of Australians believed that no wage rise was appropriate at this time. We find a very significant number wanted an increase of only $4 and a further significant percentage wanted an increase of only $8. In other words, we had out there in the market place, among the men and women of Australia whom the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is so fond of addressing and claiming for his own, a very strong view that a wage pause was appropriate and should be continued and that this was not the time to be taking money from the economy and putting additional money into the pockets of existing wage earners.

As far as the question of whether the wage pause worked to good economic effect is concerned, let me very quickly refer to some of the public statements which have been made over recent months to that effect. We find in the Reserve Bank of Australia report of 30 June 1983 that the Bank says, when talking about 1982-83:

More responsible attitudes to wage demands developed and there was widespread support for the 'Pause' in wages from about the middle of the year. This contributed to a lessening of inflationary pressure and a slowing in the loss of jobs.
We find that the Bank says later in the same report:
Restraint in wages offered, among other things, the enhanced prospect of some recovery in profits.
The Bank further says:
After increasing by about 4 per cent in the six months to December, award rates were virtually unchanged in the subsequent half year.
Later, the report goes on:
However, towards the end of the year there may have been some restoration of profitability flowing from the decline in real unit labour costs.

We find that the Confederation of Australian Industry, in its submission to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, confirmed the value of the wage pause. On 11 April 1983 at the National Economic Summit Conference the Treasurer, Mr Keating, said
. . . devaluation and the slowing of wage increases has placed our international competitive position, for the moment, not far from the best it has been since the early 1970s.
We find on page 27 of Treasury Statement No. 1, put down by the Government in the recent Budget, the following words:

The rate of increase in the indexes of award rates of pay delcline sharply in the six months following the commencement of the wages pause: over the six months to end-June 1983, the index of average weekly award rates of pay for adult wage and salary earners increased by 0.3 per cent compared with an increase of 4.0 per cent over the six months to end-December 1982.
A little later in the same document we find:
. . . which suggests that the 'wages pause' was effective during this period.

So we had in place a mechanism which had broad public support, a mechanism which was beneficial in respect of inflation and employment. We now have the Government stepping in and sabotaging that and, as part of its great agreement with the trade unions, putting in wage rises which it admits will create greater unemployment.

There is a great deal of debate which tends to obscure the simplicity of that case. We found last week, for example that Mr Willis made a great play of the fact that we will have economic growth of five per cent by mid-1984, which will bring an employment growth of 1.5 per cent. I do not wish to attribute bad motives to Mr Willis-I do not think that under Standing Orders I am allowed to, anyway-but I listened to the reports of that and I read the reports of what Mr Willis was saying last week and it all sounded as though it was something new, something which suggested that as the months were going by things were getting better under the economic administration of this Government. But there is an extraordinary sameness about what Mr Willis was putting out as a great boost for the Hawke Government last week and what it has put down in the Budget in August through the mouth of Mr Keating. Of course, the statistics that Mr Willis quoted were exactly the same as the statistics which were put forward by Mr Keating. Sure, the Government expects a 1.5 per cent rise in employment. That is the Budget figure. That is the figure which was so proudly produced by Mr Willis last week as though it was something new. But the Budget also says that the work force will rise by 2 per cent and that there will be rising unemployment. So we get this double talk in a sense, this creation of the impression that because of this accord, because of what the Government is doing, things are getting better when I think for most Australians a situation of rising unemployment does not really fit that description.

This debate is taking place at a time when in fact we do not know how badly things are running. The August Australian Bureau of Statistics figures are so bad that everybody, including the Opposition, hopes they are a statistical aberration. Nobody could hope that it is correct that we have had the participation rate drop since the Hawke Government came to power in March. I think there has been a 1.5 per cent reduction in the last few months. Nobody could hope that we could have the sort of massive new unemployment which appears to have been created in the month of August and which suggests that Mr Hawke's Government, far from creating 150,000 jobs, or 90,000 during the year as was predicted in the Budget, has seen a growth in employment of 100 Australians in its first five months in office.

So all I would want to say in this debate is that I join, no doubt with the Government, in hoping that the ABS statistics of last month are wrong. But if those figures are right and if September reflects the sort of trend which is demonstrated by the August ABS figures, what has been a mistake to this point- this walking away from wage restraint-ceases to be a mistake and becomes a tragedy. I am sorry, from the point of view of having an accurate and informed debate, that we are not having this debate a week later because I suspect that both the Opposition and the Government would be better placed then so see whether we are in the sort of trouble that the Hawke Budget predicted or whether we are indeed in something far worse.

I do not believe that the Government can claim that it is appropriate to raise wages by 4.3 per cent. It cannot claim that it is appropriate to do that because it has restored the profit share. It cannot claim that it is appropriate to do that because Australia has regained its competitiveness. I do not believe, therefore, that there is any logical basis on which it can claim that what it is doing will help employment. I think that a fair bit of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission demonstrates the serious difficulties we are in, that we continue to be in and make the Government's wage stance unacceptable. The following statement is made in the Commission's judgment:

As in the case which led to the pause, there was little disagreement on the state of the economy. The ACTU described the economy as being 'in a very dismal state'. The Confederation of Australian Industry said that there is no indicator of economic activity which is not in a worse position . . . The Federal Government submitted that the realities identified at the summit had not changed : the economy was in deep recession and the process of recovery would necessarily be slow.

The unemployment rate has risen since December, 1982, the overall profitability of business remains low and interest rates remain relatively high. Our inflation rate is still seriously out of line with those of our trading partners.
The Commission then went on to say:
But there are signs of improvement in the economy.

It dealt with things such as the breaking of the drought and the international recovery which are, of course, matters which are completely outside the hands of the present Government. But after listing what has improved, the Commission made the following important follow up:

Both the ACTU and the CAI described the signs of recovery as tentative and both said the improvements must be seen in the context of an economy in deep recession. The Business Council of Australia warned that 'wages policy should be established taking fully into account the deep relevance of the competitive requirements of the trade-competitive sector'.
I wish to make one last quote from the judgment. The Commission said:
The outlook, according to the Federal Government-
that is this Government represented here today by Senator Walsh and his officials-

is for a continuing increase in the rate of unemployment during 1983-84, despite the growth in employment, and a further substantial decline in private business fixed investment because of the high level of excess capacity.

I hope that I have made clear why the Opposition is concerned at the course the Government has taken in this area, and this legislation is but a small part of the Government's overall approach. However, the only basis on which the Hawke Government can claim that what it is doing is proper, is decent and is in any way in accord with what it promised the Australian people is to get up and argue that it is the least worst option; that it is in fact not possible by any other means to get a better result than the miserable failure it is predicting for the Australian people at the moment. What we are faced with is quite clear and is becoming clearer day by day and week by week. What is quite clear is that something called industrial relations reality requires and indeed dictates that those in jobs must have full indexation. The trade union movement, in its accord with the Government, has succeeded in achieving a position where there is dictation that those who are in jobs, whether one lives perilously as a politican or very comfortably as a permanent public servant, must have full indexation. Seventy per cent of the Australian people supported the pause. That view has been discarded in the name of industrial relations reality. I think this situation is disgusting. I think that for a government to be impotent in the face of that 70 per cent approval is nothing short of pathetic. This legislation is just one part of a pathetic essay in impotence so, I support it with very deep regret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I rise to support the Salaries and Wages Pause Act Repeal Bill 1983. I do so because it is an essential component of our prices and incomes policy and because it represents the end of a very draconian piece of legislation. The Act this Bill seeks to repeal suspended the powers of various authorities to make or vary awards or determinations in relation to the remuneration and conditions of employment of Commonwealth employees for 12 months. In view of the very sensible and realistic decision handed down by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission last Friday week, this Bill is essential if the rights and conditions of Commonwealth employees are to be protected and, above all, if this large group of workers is not to be disadvantaged in any way, especially when compared with State government employees or those in the private sector. As the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) pointed out, unless this Act is repealed quickly, obvious anomalies and inequities would arise which would lead to unnecessary industrial problems.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill we are debating is an integral part of this Government's decision to return to a centralised form of wage fixation. Under the wages pause, real income levels fell by more than 11 per cent and those hardest hit were the lower income families and those on average weekly earnings paying off mortgages and so on. If the freeze had continued, enormous pressure would have built up within the economy, so much so that it would have led to excessive wage demands and industrial disputation. That no doubt would have pleased the Opposition. But the Government wants to see a return to an orderly and fair system of wage fixation under which wage demands can be met in a way which will do least damage to economic stability and income distribution. What the Opposition is proposing, or at least what I think it is proposing-it depends on whether we listen to Mr Macphee or Mr Howard--

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't hear Peacock at all.

—I will get on to that one. What the Opposition proposes is a continuation of the wages pause for an indefinite period. Under the alternative- or should I say non-alternative-put forward by the Opposition, thousands of Australian families would see their household incomes further eroded and the end result would be a total collapse in consumer confidence and a dramatic turn in retail sales. Of course, what the Opposition will not tell us is exactly how long the wages freeze would have lasted and what precisely it would have done after it had finished. The former Treasurer, Mr Howard, proposes a free-for-all, a return to the so-called free market situation, with a whole range of private deals between employers and unions. In other words, what Mr Howard proposes amounts to a system wherein the strong unions get stronger and richer while the less powerful unions get nothing and their members suffer a severe loss in real wages. At the same time the Opposition would not repeal the Salaries and Wages Pause Act, which would mean that thousands of Commonwealth employees would also suffer a severe loss in real incomes. Quite clearly, the Opposition has no firm policy on prices and incomes. The statements emanating from the Opposition benches are conflicting, naive and totally inappropriate in the present economic climate. Opposition senators are content to sit and criticise this Government for implementing a very thorough and realistic wages policy when they have no alternative to put in its place.

SPEECH.PARA: The objective of this Bill is to return us to the situation whereby Commonwealth employees will be treated in exactly the same way as everybody else who comes under the jurisdiction of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is certainly worth pointing out that the vast majority of workers affected by this Bill are earning between $12,000 and $14,000 a year-well below the average weekly earnings. More than half of them are fourth division officers and manual workers who have families to support, mortgages to pay and probably in most cases loans or hire purchase contracts to meet. What the Opposition proposes is to deny these people the right to the recent 4.3 per cent pay increase granted by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is worth looking at the decision handed down by Sir John Moore on Friday 23 September. In support of the decision to end the wage pause, Sir John said:

. . . it is our firm belief that to delay national wage adjustments beyond the time decided by us would not be sustainable industrially and that the immediate economic advantages perceived by the Confederation of Australian Industry could be more than offset by the damage done to the Government's economic policy.

In other words, if the wages pause were prolonged, as the Opposition has suggested, the resulting industrial strife would seriously undermine the economic recovery which is now taking place. In the Australian of last Thursday the results of the latest survey of consumer sentiment, carried out by the Institute of Applied Economics and Social Research, showed that Australian consumers are now more optimistic about the nation's economic future than at any time in the past two years. I believe that the return to an orderly system of centralised wage fixing will enhance this feeling in the community and will result in a massive leap in retail sales. This will no doubt flow through to our manufacturing industries and, of course, to our service industries and will result in the creation of more permanent jobs. The alternative is too frightening to contemplate because what the Opposition and people like the Queensland Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, obviously want is more chaos, a total loss of consumer confidence and massive industrial disruption. As Sir John Moore , in his judgment last Friday week, said:
. . . we have decided that in the current circumstances, a return to a centralised system of the kind we have provided offers the best prospects for industrial stability and economic recovery.

I think it is worth pointing out to the Senate that since we came to power the number of industrial disputes has fallen considerably and our attempts to bring about a climate of conciliation and co-operation have largely been successful. The unions for their part have given a commitment to act with restraint. The fact that there has been very little disputation throughout the period of the wages pause is a credit to the trade union movement in this country. But to ask them to endure any further drop in real wages or income levels, given the fact that they have already fallen by 11 per cent or more over the last 12 months, is really asking too much. I seriously doubt whether the wages pause has been successful in achieving the massive increase in the number of jobs that it was supposedly meant to achieve. The wages pause was merely a gimmick initiated by a very desperate government with no long term goals or economic strategy. Last December when I asked Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, the then Minister representing the Treasurer, a question relating to what would occur after the proposed wages freeze, she said:
If there is a wages pause that is to be effective for a period of, say, up to 12 months, then it would be in the light of the experience of that that future policy decisions would need to be made.

In light of this experience, what has the Opposition decided? The fact is that it does not know. It is in a state of total confusion and in effect has not decided a single thing in relation to future wages policy. If it really wants to return to the Howard formula of a free-for-all, it should look closely at what happened in 1981 upon the abandonment of wage indexation. The number of industrial disputes in the following six to 12 months rose dramatically. Indeed, the wages explosion which occurred in 1981-82 can be directly attributed to the adoption of the free market arrangement.

The Opposition would do itself a favour by listening to Mr Macphee who seems to support the notion of centralised wage fixation. The Opposition is not only out of step with the reality of the present economic problems confronting us but also is quite clearly out of step with the nation's business leaders. At the National Economic Summit Conference held in the national Parliament in April, Sir Peter Abeles, among others, gave his support to the decision at the Summit to endorse the Australian Labor Party's prices and incomes accord. He said:

The third achievement which has come out of this Summit and which is so very vital for our economic future, particularly after the first two achievements I have described, is that we have unanimously agreed, even though some of the delegates have reservations, to return to centralised wage fixing by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which has served this country so well over the years since Federation.
He went on to say:

At this very late stage, Prime Minister, I wish to point out that the prices and income accord was initiated by the ACTU and your party when it was in Opposition and was finalised before the election. It is an initiative which basically has been confirmed not only by an election but by the parties to this Summit. Therefore, to formalise what we have experienced and agreed over the past four days I challenge you, Sir, I challenge the Government and the ACTU to make a bilateral agreement into a trilateral agreement. I make this challenge as the private sector provides 75 per cent of employment in Australia. Therefore, it would be only an extension of the spirit of this Summit if business were incorporated as the third party of this accord, as an equal partner. I am sure that you, Sir, would not like to feel, as most of us felt during the early days of this Conference, as though we have been invited to play single tennis against a championship doubles combination.
I hope that you and the Government and our friends in the ACTU will take up this challenge urgently.

The Government is well aware of the problems which could be created by a massive leap in wages, especially in the current economic climate. That is why we support a return to a centralised wage fixation system under which increases such as the one granted by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission last week can be controlled in a manner which is fair for all Australians. Under the Howard formula of free market wage agreements, the recovery that is now under way in Australia would be seriously threatened and could create another 1981- style wages explosion. I think it is worth noting paragraphs 17, 18, 19, 20 and 21 of the final communique from the National Economic Summit, and I will read those paragraphs for the benefit of honourable senators opposite:

17. Union participants have emphasised the role that maintenance of real wages has in job created through the stimulation of consumer demand and the maintenance of a sound industrial relations environment.
18. The trade union movement also recognises that while the maintenance of real wages is a key objective, in a period of economic crises, as now applying, it will be an objective over time.

19. All parties believe that the principles of wage fixation should be such, as to provide wage justice to employees whilst seeking to ensure that wage increases do not give added impetus to inflation or unemployment.

20. It is believed that a centralised approach to wage fixation is the most equitable means by which the objectives can be met. It is recognised that if a centralised system is to work effectively as the only way in which wage increases are generated, a suppression of sectional claims is essential except in special or extraordinary circumstances proved before the centralised wage fixing authority.

21. This Summit therefore proposes that the parties should as a matter of priority develop the option of a return to a centralised system under the auspices of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

The arguments which have been put forward by the Opposition on this Bill clearly show a lack of direction and certainly a lack of experience in respect of industrial relations matters. Over the weekend we had the spectacle of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, explaining to his Federal Council that the shadow Ministry's approach to wage fixation was that the system had to be more flexible and had to maximise opportunities for employment growth. Unfortunately, he would not elaborate. Quite clearly, he could not elaborate because that is all the Opposition's policy on wages consists of. As I said previously, this Bill is an essential part of the Government's prices and incomes policy and will result in a fairer system of wage determination for thousands of Australians. I am proud to support the Bill and commend it to all all honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, has expressed to the Senate the Opposition's view with regard to the repeal of the wages pause legislation. He has stated on our behalf that the Salaries and Wages Pause Act Repeal Bill is not opposed by the Opposition. It will be recalled that the introduction of the wages pause was an act of the former Government at a time when there was rising unemployment and considerable concern at the relationship between the profitability of enterprises and their capacity to provide employment. It will be recalled that all State governments joined with the then Federal Government in instituting the wages pause. It was at the instigation of State governments in particular that the funds released from the wages pause as they related to Commonwealth Government employees were for employment creation programs. It was said, I think by Senator Foreman, that we were not able to give a catalogue of the numbers of jobs that were able to be provided through the wages pause. I would point out that the State governments, with some of their own funds, were at liberty to create the programs for which they had been pressuring the Commonwealth Government for funds. Arising from those plans at the State level, and in some cases at the local government level, as I understand it, a number of activities were able to be undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: It seemed to me that some of the proposals that came from the State governments that more funds would be the answer to more jobs were not as easily fulfilled as they might have expected. However, all the funds that were saved in the Commonwealth Government sector were released to the States and the Territories for their use in employment creation programs. Of course, the largest benefit that was to come from the wages pause was to be measured not only in terms of job creation programs but also in the effect on the wages level generally and the way in which that affected the capacity of employers to provide real and permanent jobs and increased numbers of jobs. We were pleased that in the June quarter the measurement of the average weekly earnings showed that there was a rise of only 0.9 per cent. That was one of the strongest measures we had of the effectiveness of the wages pause that had been accepted not only in the Commonwealth Government sector but also in many other parts of employment throughout Australia. That 0.9 per cent rise in average weekly earnings in June was the lowest quarterly increase in male total earnings for four years. I think it could be claimed that it was very largely able to be attributed to the wages pause and the attitude in the Community at that time with regard to understanding the relationship between wage levels and employment opportunities.

Whilst we were able to say that that low rise in the June quarter was welcome, it did mean that we still had wage levels at roughly double the rate of those of our major trading partners. So although we had achieved a very low increase in that quarter our wage levels were still dangerously high at that time. We were still uncompetitive in comparison with those with whom we were trading. If we are to receive the full benefit from any increases in activity that come from overseas or through our own economic recovery following the breaking of the drought and so on, it would seem to me that what is important is the level of our wages, the capacity of employers to provide employment, and return on investment. I would have thought that that was what we would all be seeking.

I think that what has been said, and in some cases it was outlined by Senator Chaney, with regard to attitudes of employers is something that ought to be said again. The Confederation of Australian Industry quite frankly put foward its view that the wages pause should extend at least to the end of 1983. Of course, that organisation was talking about our competitiveness and our capacity for employment. The Confederation's submission to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission preceding the recent wages case outlined, in particular, its attitude to the wages pause and to the extension of the wages pause.

This afternoon I want to spend a little time looking at some of the submissions made by the employer bodies. The Australian Industries Development Association in its last publication, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Institute of Public Affairs have all drawn attention to wage levels and in most cases have addressed themselves also to the on-cost of labour on wage levels. Whereas we might recognise that there was a 4.3 per cent increase in wages granted by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission we need to recognise that , in addition there are the flow-on costs of the on-costs for every dollar that is spent in wages. Firstly, the submission made by the Confederation of Australian Industry and secondly in the recent publication of the IPA we see that anything between 35 and 40 per cent is the additional cost of labour following any payments that are made.

The IPA booklet that addresses itself to the costs of labour shows us that, on the figures it was using in its summary of a payment of, say, $354 per week, which would include some overtime and some shift allowances and things of that sort, a very considerable amount is added to every dollar paid-for annual leave and loading, public holidays, long service leave, sick and compassionate leave, allowances, non-productive paid time, superannuation, workers compensation, payroll tax, employee amenities and other costs. The figures that the IPA gives show that there is an increase of about 44 per cent on wages for these additional costs. I think the salutary thing is that when we look at our wage level per hour we should look also at the other amounts that need to be found by any employer as he looks at the wages levels. The figure given by the IPA is about 44 per cent. I think the CAI gives a figure closer to about 35 per cent on its survey of major employers. If we do not quibble about the detail in fine point we can look at something like 35 to 40 per cent as an on-cost on labour whenever we are seeking to measure whether we are productive or what our costs per hour are in those industries where it is crucial to be competitive in a unit cost.

These are the things that I would draw attention to at this time as we are looking at repealing the legislation which relates to the wages pause. It is not just a matter of talking about the fact that our Commonwealth employees have had the wages pause applied to them but rather to look at our attitude, in general, to employment, to opportunities for widening employment and to look at the reason why it is so difficult for employers to provide greater employment opportunities in the foreseeable future. If we have, as we undoubtedly do have, an attitude from the Government that full indexation is the approach to wages policy and that full indexation is to be applied from the March quarter of this year in accordance with that policy, then it stands to reason that there is considerable cost per head for employers as they seek to provide employment in the coming months. There is the additional on-cost that comes to them on every dollar that they expend. I think there are difficulties ahead of us in overtaking the enormous number of people who cannot find employment or who are in employment which is at great risk.

It seems to me that it is timely for us to look at some of these matters as we address a Bill related to the wages pause that had, during the time it was applied, some benefit. I think it certainly has had the effect of dampening down that rate of increase that had been running through 1981 and 1982. The employment figures given to us in any of the Budget Papers or in any of the documents of the National Economic Summit Conference make us very concerned indeed about our capacity to employ, or to give opportunities for growth in the economy through productive employment. I think it is time that we looked at the responsibilities of all those seeking wage increases and those who have to provide them and governments which have to put the public interest point of view quite firmly and to look at what occurred with a pause in wages and what could be the objective of a longer wages pause had it been able to continue at least until the end of this year.

The State governments which supported the wages pause now have the effects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission increase flowing through their Budgets. State charges in the budgets will increase, in many instances, those on -cost figures which I mentioned. It is a spiral that was broken for a short time by the Salaries and Wages Pause Act. I think it was a very useful exercise in what we were able to do.

The Government's policy is to support full indexation at a time when our major trading partners have reduced their cost of living increases to about half of what our increases have been. The inflation rates of most of our trading partners have been very much lower than ours. So, if we embark upon a system of full indexation we will not be competitive with our trading partners in the near future. The recent economic survey by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development confirmed that if Australia is to take advantage of the benefits of the economic recovery of the United States of America which is now spreading through some of the industrialised world there must be a much quicker pick-up in our international competitiveness. I fail to see how we can reach a greater level of competitiveness than we have at present with our inflation rate and full wages policy. Although the Budget predicts that our inflation rate is likely to fall significantly over the next 12 months, it will still be higher than the rates of our trading partners. The excessive wage growth in recent years has been part of that disability. If that is now to continue with full indexation at a higher level of inflation than the levels of our partners then I think the argument for a wage pause continuation has already been made through that OECD survey. The benefits that we felt, I think, have been one advantage that we cannot ignore. But if we look at any surveys of international levels of either inflation or activity and compare them with our own we will see that we still have a very great distance to go.

I was interested recently to read the booklet from the Legislative Research Service entitled The CPI and Wage Indexation in which it again draws attention to, I suppose, the relevance of the CPI and wage levels or wage adjustments. It draws attention to the fact that we have sometimes had taken into account and sometimes not, the effect of the terms of trade on wage submissions, the taxes on goods and services and the effects of devaluation of our currency. I think that, as the unions press for their wage adjustments, they need to look at some of the changes that will flow through from the present Budget and from the general economic decisions that will be taken. If we have pressure for full indexation on CPI measurement, I can only think that we may have more difficulties ahead of us in arguing these cases before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission than people may predict through believing that we have a central system with full indexation and, ergo, industrial harmony.

It is of interest to see the outstanding claims that are before the Government and the Commission at present, notably the claims of the building industry that are before an anomalies commission and could affect the wage levels of about 130 ,000 people. That could lead to pressures for a flow-on into other industries, which would require a decision on whether these sorts of figures, ranging up to something like $20 a week, are to be regarded as proper claims within the terms of the prices and incomes accord. There is also, of course, the most recent Arbitration Commission decision on its conditions for the acceptance of a 4.3 per cent increase across the board.

I believe that in the public interest the building industry agreement ought to be subjected to the strongest opposition by the Government. I raised with Senator Button today questions with regard to statements by the Australian Council of Trade Unions that it can expect not to have a great deal of trouble with some of its claims. It makes me wonder just what will be the outcome of the matter that is before the Commission and how that will affect the other wage levels, in addition to the 4.3 per cent increase that has been awarded through the national wage decision. If the Government does serve the public interest in the way that I think we all hope it will, it will give strong opposition to those sectional claims which not only endanger its own wages policy but certainly also endanger the capacity of Australian industry to employ and the capacity of the Australian economy to show some signs of recovery and to provide increased opportunity for all.

It is with these thoughts in mind that I join with Senator Chaney in his comments on the repeal of the Salaries and Wages Pause Act at this time. Whilst it may be thought that some sort of industrial peace can be achieved with full indexation, it could be achieved at the cost of those who have no opportunity for employment; it could be achieved at the cost of those who are at present in jobs which will not be able to be sustained if there is not a sense of reality- not just industrial reality but economic reality-in terms of looking at the capacity to employ, the capacity to produce and the capacity to sell those things that will give us some economic recovery as soon as it can be achieved within Australia. It is with these comments that I join with Senator Chaney in saying that the repeal of this Act is not opposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Salaries and Wages Pause Act Repeal Bill 1983. Perhaps it was a misnomer to call it the Salaries and Wages Pause Act because it did not make all wages and salaries pause. What it did was limit its effect to the salaries and wages of the Public Service. I think that should be remembered: This was not a blanket stop to wage and salary increases throughout the country; it paused or froze wages in the Public Service at both the high level and the very low level. One must remember that, while a First Division or Second Division permanent head or assistant secretary would not be too badly affected by such a wage pause, there are thousands of employees in the Commonwealth Public Service who do represent the lower paid sections of the community. To them this Act represents hardship.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know of the extent to which this wage pause worked. The Australian Democrats supported the legislation when it was debated in the Senate on 16 December 1982. We pleaded then that a moratorium on government charges should accompany it. The Fraser Government of the day rejected the Democrats' request to bring in supplementary legislation to give some relief to people whose wages and salaries were frozen. We requested that at least government charges should be frozen during the time of the pause. The Fraser Government introduced the wages freeze to attempt to undo some of the damage that had been wrought by the wages explosion of 1982. I think all of us last year were alarmed by that explosion. That explosion followed-I make these comments in view of the remarks of Senator Chaney and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle-the Fraser Government's success in undermining and destroying the centralised wage fixing system. A mad scramble for wage increases followed its collapse. I hope that a future government will attack the centralised wage fixing system at its peril.

The aim of the wage pause was to save jobs, to redirect the money saved into job creation projects, to reduce the wages component of Australia's inflation rate, to make Australian products more competitive on the world market and to set an example. I give credit to the previous Government for the fact that it did set an example. There was a slow down in wage increases or applications for wage increases generally during the wage pause. However, it is hard to tell whether the freeze saved jobs. We do know, unhappily, that unemployment continued to rise during the wage pause and Australia still has a problem of high inflation. The wage pause had no palpable effect-by that I do not mean it had no effect-on inflation. Essentially the wages freeze was a dramatic and simplistic over-reaction to a problem that the previous Government had helped to create. It certainly was not a thought-out wages and prices policy concentrated entirely on wages while ignoring price increases. At the same time the Government adhered to its obsessive addiction to monetarist policies. Over the seven years of its tenure those policies proved disastrous, yet with the persistence of the stupid the former Government stuck to monetarism as a doctrine, almost as a dogma. Although, quite properly, we heard criticism in the time leading up to and during the last election campaign from the Australian Labor Party and from Mr Hawke about the philosophy of monetarism, it now appears that the Labor Party is embracing that philosophy as passionately and as vigorously as did the Liberal Party. One wonders what further examples of failure this Government and the previous Government need of this stupid, ridiculous policy of monetarism before they see the light.

This legislation has affected only public servants and within that broad category of employees it made no distinction on equity grounds between low income and high income government employees. Many low income earners will as a result of this legislation have had no increases for some nine months, while increases in Commonwealth and State government charges have severely eroded their living standards. We in the Democrats say it is time this legislation was repealed. It penalised groups indiscriminately, without any sense of reason or justice. For example, it effectively penalised pharmacists by freezing their dispensing fees, but the Fraser Government obstinately and consistently refused the request of the Democrats to peg the incomes of lawyers, accountants and doctors. It left them to charge exactly what they pleased. The present Government at least seems to be approaching the problem by looking at both sides , both wages and prices-at not only the incomes of public servants and other wage earners but also the incomes of professionals such as doctors, lawyers and accountants.

We hope that the repeal of this legislation might be accompanied by expansionary measures. Unemployment has two facets. It is not only a human problem that brings misery and suffering to hundreds of thousands of human beings but it is also self-defeating in budgetary terms. For the last five, six or seven Budgets we have seen unemployment have this effect. As more and more people become unemployed because of restrictionist monetary policies, the less income the Government collects through taxes and the more it has to pay out in unemployment benefits. The diminution of incoming revenue through lost taxes and the additional expenditure on increased dole payments has one effect: It increases the deficit. Sheer logic demands the acknowledgement of that as an inescapable result of restrictionist monetary policies.

Increased deficits put pressure on interest rates, leading to inflation. A restrictionist monetary policy has the extraordinarily clever feature of increasing unemployment at the same time as it increases the rate of inflation. One wonders when government and those in the ivory tower of the Treasury Department will wake up to themselves and realise that the only way out of the recession in which Australia finds itself is through a consumer led recovery. That will not be brought about by the kinds of restrictionist policies we have seen in this country for the last seven years.

The Democrats support this legislation but we say in passing that we are not enamoured of the kinds of policies being followed by this Government. There seems to be no long range indicative planning with respect to the high tariffs that prevail in this country, or towards the advance of technology and the preparation of Australia to cope with the massively increasing rate of unemployment that will be caused by the silicon chip, automation and so forth. We seem to be drifting through a group of ad hoc policies without the application of any visionary concepts in the long term. We support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleagues Senator Chaney and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle mentioned earlier, the Opposition does not oppose the repeal of the Salaries and Wages Pause Act. However, a number of the matters that have been discussed in the course of this debate need attention. I will first consider some of the remarks made by Senator Chipp, who has just resumed his seat. He concluded his remarks by saying that the answer to Australia's recessionary problems lay in a consumer led recovery. I agree that that is certainly one aspect of the recovery that must come in this country, but I fail to see what benefits that will bring to Australian industry and therefore to Australian job seekers if consumers buy imported goods. That is a natural consequence of Australian goods being too expensive on world markets. Imported goods become relatively cheaper and people in Australia choose to buy them rather than Australian goods.

SPEECH.PARA: That point must be recognised as being at the core of the faults of our present economic situation. The cost of labour in this country is very high compared with that in other countries. As a result our goods are not easily saleable on world markets and goods reach the Australian market from overseas manufactured sites in such a way as to force Australian goods off the shelves. That is one of the major causes of unemployment. While our labour costs remain relatively high it will be absolutely impossible to put back to work the 700,000 people who are presently unemployed. Senator Chipp drew our attention to the need to do something for the unemployed. It was very significant that the wages pause provided moneys for State governments to spend on job creation programs. There was also, of course, some direct expenditure by the Federal Government in this area. As a result of the wages pause, approximately $300m was made available last financial year to extend job opportunities for the unemployed in the States .

That money was made available as a direct result of the savings in wages which would otherwise have gone to public servants who were already in employment. It was a direct attempt to alleviate the position of the unemployed by creating jobs for them without necessarily adding to the further wage benefit that would have been received by people already in employment. The fundamental point was totally missed by Senator Chipp in his remarks. I do not know his real reasons for supporting the repeal of this legislation, because clearly he was unable to tell us precisely what was his understanding of the wages pause.

I make that point because it seems that he sought to wander into areas of economics and debate very broad questions of economics which were not relevant to the immediate questions arising from the legislation before us. A number of those matters are important to an understanding of the present economic recession, but they are certainly not critical to the most fundamental issue before us and that is the relative cost of labour in this country compared with the rest of the world. That is the reason that we have unemployment. There is only one way we can improve the unemployment situation.
