We have to improve our methods of production, sell our goods more cheaply on world markets, and get wages relatively lower than those in the rest of the world.

One other point needs to be made. One need look only to the United States to provide an example of a country whose economy has significantly improved as a result of wages being brought under control and inflation reduced. In the last two years when policies have been adopted to promote a free flow in the market place there has been a significant reduction in the cost of labour and hence a drop in the inflation rate, from 20 per cent to under 5 per cent. Consequently, there has been a revival in the economy. All the indicators are that the growth rate in the American economy is of the order of 5 or 6 per cent. Some commentators put it even higher at 8 per cent. Thus, there is a direct relationship between the control of inflation and the creation of jobs. That is exactly what the wages pause legislation was about in the first place. I remind the Senate that the legislation was introduced by the Fraser Government with the objective of using the Budget funds saved by not increasing wages for public servants directly on assistance to the unemployed. I believe that was a most significant and worthwhile objective; one that was supported, albeit equivocally , by the then Opposition.

I very well recall the former Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, last December hopping from foot to foot trying to find a position to stand on with respect to that question; it seemed that he changed his mind every couple of minutes. Finally, a gallup poll decided the matter for him. The poll came out just before Christmas, I think, and demonstrated that most people in Australia supported the wages pause. Consequently, Mr Hayden changed his mind and went in that direction. One can only wonder how it was that he succeeded in staying in office as Leader of the Opposition for a least another month after that performance.

It might be significant to note, too, that given the support in the community for this scheme in the first place, during the period of the wage pause the proportion of people who supported it, as measured by the gallup poll, actually rose to a high level of about 70 per cent, I think, in about July of this year. That was the number of people who wanted to see the pause continued. That coincides directly with those critics of the wage decision brought down a week or two ago by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission who are saying that the wage pause ought to continue until at least the end of December so that the benefits can be fully wrought from that very significant decision. That is obviously a failing on the part of the present Government. It has abandoned that policy and has gone, instead, for a policy of appeasement of the trade union movement by granting and supporting a 4.3 per cent wage increase, as granted by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the last few weeks, and throwing overboard the whole principle of keeping labour costs under control .

The result of any decision on indexation along the lines of that announced by the Commission in recent times is only to build into future costs the cost of inflation as it is at present. No one can see how that can possibly assist in the creation of job opportunities in Australia. I call it an act of appeasement because that is simply what it is, and that so-called accord between the unions and the Government on matters of wages and inflation control is just so much hot air. One has to say that also in regard to that much vaunted special relationship that the Government is supposed to have-perhaps it is only the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who has it-with the trade union movement. That is now absolutely recognised as having been a total failure. Clearly the Government is falling over backwards to appease the trade union movement in any way that it possibly can.

Those effects will have their presence felt in the year ahead, as we look down towards the outcome of the 1983-84 Budget, and it is those things which will give little comfort to the unemployed as they view the prospects in the year ahead. We have recently heard the Prime Minister telling us that we are looking forward to growth rates in this economy of about 5 per cent and 6 per cent. I wish the Prime Minister well with that calculation, but if he persists in building into policy the kinds of wage increases the he is now doing by virtue of his special relationship with the trade unions, we shall see a failure ever to achieve anything like such a growth rate, and we can look forward to higher rates of inflation as well.

There is only one other matter to which I wanted to advert in regard to this legislation. That was the choice that has been made by this Government, in its so-called rush to job creation, by changing the previous Government's policies in regard to the creation of national assets. I refer to the proposed Alice Springs-Darwin railway, which is of very great concern to the Northern Territory and, of course, to my State of South Australia. It is of vital importance to the development of the country from the point of view of defence and the extension of the very worthwhile uranium mining prospects in South Australia and the Northern Territory, in which, of course, the Government has no interest whatsoever and is determined to defeat. In that regard, the railway would open enormous opportunities for future development. I want to bring this point clearly to the attention of Government senators who just do not understand that the dollar that one spends today on creating a job is just fine, and it keeps people in work for that day; but the dollar that one spends on creating something that will generate more jobs in the future is the dollar that will multiply as the years go by and generate enormous potential growth in this economy and provide jobs not only for those who are unemployed now but for those who will be coming on in the decades ahead. That is what Liberal policies were about. I mention the railway as being one example of that.

Another very significant example was the water development program, which this Government has scrapped in favour of short term time-filling operations, such as filling in holes in roads and digging them out again to refill them, such as are being proposed under the community employment program. One finds that the kind of prospect of job creation in that area is somewhat negative when one talks to local government bodies which, in very general terms, are quite well off with funds these days. One finds that they are applying for benefits and for parts of the Commonwealth employment program as a matter of course to receive funds for particular projects knowing that they will probably get them because the money is being poured out through that program as if by men with no arms, and local government really does not know what to do with the money. That kind of silliness will not generate long term job opportunities in the future but, rather, it will be wasted on programs and projects that are of no lasting benefit to the community.

Whilst the Government's approach in this area contains that element of compassion and humanity which all of us in this Parliament share in regard to the unemployed, it certainly does not offer long term opportunities for people to be sure that their future in this world of ours will be assured in the years ahead. The Government will have to face those questions further down the track when the results of its misguided policies become evident. However, in regard to the repeal of this legislation, whilst the Opposition does not oppose the repeal , it is clear that the wage pause has not yet gone far enough to redress the imbalances between the cost of labour in this country and that in the rest of the world. The best solution for the future lies in continued restraint and the exercise of that restraint by the Government and by all parties in our community in such a way as we can limit wage increases generally. That will certainly not be enhanced by the Government's policies of supporting wage increases such as we have seen recently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Government in the repeal of the Salaries and Wages Pause Act. In doing so, I support the decision last week by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to grant a 4.3 per cent wage rise to Australian workers, under certain conditions-namely, signification by the union concerned or those participating in an award that they will abide by the rather stringent guidelines which were promulgated by the Commission. I support that return to centralised wage fixing for the Australian work force as carrying into effect not only the principles of the accord, which were scorned by Senator Messner, but the decision of the National Economic Summit Conference, which comprised much more than the unions and the Government and had the support of the employers within the Australian system at that time, in any case.

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly want to comment on some aspects of Senator Messner's speech. He said that there is a relationship between the control of inflation and the creation of jobs. I do not think that any honourable senator would disagree with that. But what he missed was the very obvious point that there is also a relationship between the sustaining of jobs within the economy, the creation of new jobs, and the possible level of industrial disputation. The Arbitration Commission, in bringing down the decision in favour of the 4.3 per cent wage rise, said this, amongst other things:

. . . it is our firm belief that to delay national wage adjustments beyond the time decided by us would not be sustainable industrially and that the immediate economic advantages perceived by the CAI could be more than offset by the damage done to the Government's economic policy . . .
It went on:

while it is useful to distinguish between industrial relations and economic considerations, in practice there is close connection between them-the costs of industrial disputes and industrial instability have a bearing on the economy and its capacity to advance the interests of employers, employees and the community generally.

I believe that that is actually the kernel of the decision by the Commission. The Commission's decision, which in accord with the prices and incomes accord and along the lines indicated by the National Economic Summit Conference, creates a situation-with those stringent conditions which the Commission requires of those participating in an award before it is indexed-where those who conduct trade and commerce in the various public and private business enterprises throughout our economy, create the wealth, create the jobs, can operate in a much more stable atmosphere than would be the case if we tried to hold down the legitimate expectations of Australian employees that they should obtain an increase in wages to deal with the ravages of inflation, which increase they have forgone during the period of the wages pause. It would be quite unreasonable to expect that there would not have been massive industrial disputation over the next few months as the stronger sections of the trade union movement used their muscle to grab what they could. Of course, that would always be at the expense of those less well organised or less powerfully positioned associations of workers who could not get what they ought to in order to sustain the living standards of their members. I will come to that in a moment also.

Senator Messner raised the question, although it was somewhat irrelevant, of the failure of the Federal Government to generate jobs by using its scarce tax dollars wisely. He talked about railways and job creation schemes. He is living in the nineteenth century. Senator Chipp said that this Government lacked vision as to the long term possibilities of creating wealth within the Australian economy and the sorts of jobs which we will need to create. The answer to both of them lies in the high technology summit conference which was conducted in Canberra last week. The Government clearly organised a very successful occasion which was attended by the high technology industries that will provide the new wealth, be export oriented and create new jobs within our economy. All of these matters were discussed in a very fruitful and productive manner under the charismatic, one might say, in the best sense of the word, leadership of Mr Barry Jones, the Minister for Science and Technology. Indeed, only a couple of weeks ago, we put our scarce tax dollars into a scheme which will encourage high risk venture capital into those new industries. We are doing things in that regard, but I am being a little diverted in replying to some of the remarks made by Senator Messner and Senator Chipp.

I know, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you are waiting for me to explain why the Government supports the centralised system of wage fixing as strongly as it does. We do so, firstly, because it is part of the prices and incomes accord understanding, and secondly, because the National Economic Summit endorsed the acceptance of the principles of wage fixation such as to provide wage justice while seeking to ensure that wage increases do not give added impetus to inflation or unemployment. The National Economic Summit supported a centralised approach to wage fixation as the most equitable means by which such objectives can be met. That stands in great contrast to the reports of the weekend meeting of the Federal Council of the Liberal Party, where Mr John Howard, who has been making the running on this matter over the past two or three weeks, claimed to have the full support of all members of the shadow Cabinet for a set of objectives in relation to wage fixing. He said:

. . . They rest upon a number of principles which include a recognition that our wage fixation system must be more sensitive to market realities than it has been in the past and that it must also recognise the wide variation in capacity to pay not only of different industries in Australia, but also of different firms within individual industries.

All of that is verbiage camouflaging what he is really saying, which is that the law of the jungle should prevail and the strong unions and the strong associations of employees should grab what they can from the very profitable industries and firms within industries and sections of industries operating in the very rich resource areas of Australia, the successful exporters of Australia , perhaps, whilst the weak associations of workers are continually ground down and have their living standards diminished during that process. What it further signifies is that Mr Howard has won out over the more reasonable counsel of Mr Macphee and Mr Peacock, interestingly both former holders of the portfolio of industrial relations in this country. Mr Howard, who has never held that portfolio, who has never been responsible for industrial relations in Australia, has dominated the new formulation of Liberal policy in relation to this matter and has come out with a line which is appropriate to his thinking as the former Treasurer of this country but which does not pay sufficient regard to the industrial relations aspects which, as I have explained, lie at the kernel, the centre, of the decision by the Arbitration Commission last week.

There is no doubt that a centralised system provides stability and the National Economic Summit endorsed the idea, because it allows for some confidence in planning. It is the best forum, too, in which overall economic factors in the economy can be considered, rather than individual industries or firms arriving at deals between employers and employees, which apparently is what Mr Howard wants, and which, of course, has no regard to the overall impact of such piecemeal decisions on the operation of the economy as a whole. Indeed, there is a deeply ingrained notion of fairness throughout the Australian community generated over the years since Mr Justice Higgins inaugurated our system of conciliation and arbitration. There is this deeply ingrained feeling about wage relativities and a general conviction that advances for Australian workers ought to be across the board. That it why Ms Gail Cotton of the Food Preservers Union of Australia found to her astonishment that almost all the unions right across the spectrum of so called political allegiance at the recent Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress condemned her union for its sectional approach in bringing pressure to bear on what was seen as an employer who could make certain adjustments to the wages of those employed at a particular plant, I think in that case H. J. Heinz Co. Australia Ltd. What was seen as important by the trade union movement was this notion of fairness that all Australian workers ought to be advanced over the broad spectrum rather than sectional claims being allowed to be pursued by those who have an advantage because of market place conditions for their labour in any particular instance.

The Government is supporting centralised wage fixing and it has been very heartening for us to see the ACTU taking that strong line against sectional claims. Of course, that provided the atmosphere within which the Arbitration Commission made its decision. We will continue to support centralised wage fixing and, in particular, we will put in place supporting mechanisms that will encourage the trade union movement to adhere to the undertakings it will be giving to the Commission in order to obtain the indexed awards by that public undertaking it has to give about not going outside the guidelines.

We are taking steps to cover other matters which were contained in the accord. We have established the Economic Planning Advisory Council, EPAC, which includes employer and union representation, to broaden the provision of economic information, to provide a forum for community participation, and to assist the Government in its medium and long term economic assessment. Perhaps that is something Senator Chipp would be pleased to hear. We also intend to establish a prices surveillance authority, and the legislation for that is being undertaken.

But just as important are those other measures which this Government is taking in support of the so-called social wage which allows unions to moderate their actual cash wage claims against employers and which also may have a beneficial effect on the consumer price index. Of course I refer in particular to the passage of the Medicare legislation through this chamber only two weeks ago, to come into effect on 1 February 1984. Senator Janine Haines played a sterling and sensible part during the negotiations in relation to the passage of that legislation and I think she will agree that the executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions played no small part in affirming that it was part of the understanding it had reached with the Government in the prices and incomes accord that the social wage should incorporate this Medicare program. As I say, the ACTU Executive was very supportive of the Government's bringing that particular measure to pass. Of course not only does it moderate wage demands by lessening the impact of accident of illness on the financial resources of Australian employees but also it means they do not have to pay out so much for health insurance premiums. It will also moderate demands overall by bringing about a reduction in the CPI. It is that sort of supportive activity by this Government which I know is appreciated by the trade union movement and which will help that movement to adhere to the guidelines demanded of it by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

Mr Deputy President, I do not intend to take much more of the time of the Senate in supporting this return to centralised wage fixing, except to say that we have to hope that industrial relations practitioners in Australia, whether they be within the trade union movement or amongst management, will prepare themselves for a situation where, whilst industrial disputation in relation to wage fixing will diminish, other matters will be the focus of industrial unrest. I am confident that industrial disputation will diminish because that has been the pattern. Prior to the introduction of the last indexation system industrial disputation reached an all-time high, in 1974, when 6.3 million working days were lost. Following the introduction of indexation, disputation fell to a level , in 1977-78, some 65 per cent lower than in 1973-74. Then, with the collapse of indexation and the establishment of the post-indexation wage round in the second half of 1981, the number of working days lost reached an even higher level than in the corresponding period in 1974.

So there is a very clear relationship between the diminution of industrial disputes and loss of working days through the introduction of wage indexation. One would say it is an inverse relationship, I think. So whilst I am confident that that will be the case as a result of the decision of the Arbitration Commission last week, it will mean, of course, that other matters going perhaps to hours of work per week, general safety, health and welfare and technological change questions, will be the focus of industrial unrest and of seeking to modify or change situations at the work place. It is in regard to these matters that we must encourage industrial relations practitioners to be aware that that is where the focus of their efforts must lie.
Mr Deputy President, I support the Government's repeal of this legislation and, as I say, warmly commend the Arbitration Commission for its very sensible decision of last week.

I understand that 220 jobs were provided from the $3.2m allocated, and that all of that money has in fact been allocated-and had been before the end of June. I am not certain of the total number of jobs that have been filled but I understand it is over 200 at the present time, with a high expectation that all of them will be taken up.

I personally wish to commend the officers of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations who worked with the committee and on the committee for the contribution they made to analysing the schemes put forward and in particular for very diligently looking for suitable people to fill these 220 jobs. I have met a number of people who have been employed under the wage pause program, many of them in jobs which will very likely give them the sort of experience-for example in research-which will enable them to apply for jobs and say that they have had experience, because they will have had experience. It has given many people an opportunity that they could not otherwise have had. I will not this afternoon go through the various examples that I know of, but I think it has been of tremendous benefit to a number of people.

The fact that the jobs were for a period of 12 months duration was part of the real benefit. It is a long enough time for people to get to know the job, to learn something and to be a more likely person to obtain employment in the future. It is a pity that the community employment program presently being embarked upon says that jobs will be for a period of six months. I do not believe that that is an adequate period for people without experience to get sufficient experience to be able to present themselves to an employer in a meaningful way and I hope that that aspect of the program can be changed so that real benefits can flow. Of course the pity of all this is that none of it is leading to real jobs and real careers and that is what the unemployed are particularly looking for. We need to devise ways of making sure that programs which are put into effect do lead to careers and permanent jobs.

The wage pause committee to which I referred, which allocated the funds that came into the Australian Capital Territory, presented a report to the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) in early April of this year. It was a most comprehensive report with a great deal of factual information which had been ascertained in the course of the committee's deliberations, and it contained 70 recommendations relevant to employment. It is with a great deal of sorrow that I report to you, Mr Deputy President, that the Minister for Territories and Local Government has not responded to those recommendations. He must at least have had a look at the report because he has implemented one of the recommendations. He has established the permanent advisory committee which was recommended, which is the committee now dealing with the community employment program funds.

The other 69 recommendations do not seem to have got very far at all. One of them, of particular interest in the Australian Capital Territory, concerns permanent part time employment in the Public Service and the recommendations of the committee to the Minister that he use his influence with the Government and with the Public Service Board to get permanent part time employment brought in, not as some fancy means of casual employment but as a regular part of employment . It deals also with shared employment and a number of other recommendations that are significant if one is to take the question of jobs seriously. I ask the Minister to take the time to look at these recommendations and respond to the report.

There are some other matters relating to jobs that I hope the Minister will be working on as well, including the question of the White Industries Ltd development. Prior to the election of this Government a decision was made that the project should go ahead. However, from that time until now little has been heard of it. The development would provide some 600 jobs at the construction stage and about 1,200 jobs would be provided on completion. This community needs those jobs. I believe community employment program funds could be spent perhaps more wisely in other areas to create jobs which would be of benefit. I commend the Minister on the $1.5m that he obtained and added to our share of community employment program funds on the basis of our entitlement as a State. We have had to fight frequently for that portion of funds which relates to State-type contributions. I was glad so see that the Minister recognised that and saw to it that his colleagues agreed that the money should go to the Australian Capital Territory. However, I believe that the money could have been better spent in the area of tourism and on incentives to attract business and industries to the Australian Capital Territory which will create more permanent jobs and careers for the young people of our community who are presently not able to find employment.

The community employment program will be of undoubted great benefit to many community projects and as such the community will benefit from it. But I think in terms of real jobs the money perhaps could have been spent differently. Perhaps even now some changes can be made to see that it is spent differently and in a way that is meaningful in this community. The proposals I suggest may not necessarily be appropriate in all communities. But let us look at each case individually and do what is best for the communities we are talking about. I think that in the Australian Capital Territory tourism in particular is the light at the end of the tunnel. I urge the Government to consider putting some of the community employment program funds into developments in that area. In particular I ask the Government to get on with allowing the White Industries project to go ahead. I support the repealing of this legislation, not because I think it was wrong in the beginning-it was clearly right-but because, given that there are to be wage increases throughout the community, it is appropriate and proper that Commonwealth public servants and others affected by this legislation should be in the same position as the rest of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Salaries and Wages Pause Act Repeal Bill 1983 which, as its name implies, in effect terminates the salaries and wage pause legislation initiated and introduced during 1982 by the last Government, the Government of Mr Fraser. I would like to raise some matters at the very beginning. Firstly, I refer to a short article in volume 32, No. 3 of the spring 1983 edition of Facts, which is published by the Institute of Public Affairs in Melbourne. This publication, which should be read by all honourable senators, is published four times a year and contains informed information. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: In the endless discussions about budget deficits, interest rates, taxes, wage determination, some simple economic truths are forgotten.
These are:
Our standards of living depend on how much, as a nation, we produce.
Private business enterprise, not government, produce most of the wealth and provide most of the jobs (3 out of every 4).
More welfare, and better educational and health facilities, depend on more production, not on trying to redistribute wealth that hasn't been produced.
Higher real incomes for all can only be achieved out of more production.

I adopt each one of those paragraphs. I also want to quote something that was said by Mr P. P. McGuinness in an article on the economy published in the Australian Financial Review of 12 September 1983. Mr McGuinness is, of course, the editor of that publication. He said:
There is a strange reluctance among many members of the community, and indeed even among professional economists, to accept that there is a relationship between wage rates and levels of employment.
Having discussed that sentence he went on to say:

This is not to say that wages are the only determining factor in employment, or even always the major factor. No one would assert that the present high unemployment in Australia was created solely by wage increases. But very few would assert that in the circumstances of declining per capita national income and declining international competitiveness, the sharp increases in real wages of 1981-82 had nothing to do with the increase in unemployment.

Of course, they had so very much to do with the massive increase in unemployment in the last 12 months. I might remind the Senate that Senator Hamer and I made our positions very clear when the legislation was first introduced. We believed that the legislation did not go far enough. We put to the Government the argument that in fact there ought to be an across the board cut in the salaries of senior public servants and a cut in our salaries and Ministers' salaries and that, those cuts being put into effect by legislation, we should then go to the community and ask various people within the community to take a salary cut and not just accept a freeze. Nevertheless the then Government introduced legislation which, as I shall mention in due course, proved to be very successful. The then Opposition-the present Australian Labor Party Government- attacked and most severely criticised the legislation we introduced. In support of that allegation I quote from the prices and incomes accord, that infamous agreement made in February this year. The document stated:
. . . the short sighted political expediency which the Fraser Government has sought to impose in the form of a wages freeze.
Later on it stated:
Such one sided inequitable wages policies are completely repudiated by the parties to this statement as manifestly unfair;
And again:

In contrast to the Fraser Government's assertion that a wage freeze will make more funds available for employment, the reality is that a reduction in demand, through severely reduced real incomes for most of the population, is bound to accentuate economic recession and increase unemployment.

Of course, as soon as the Labour Party got into government that nonsense was treated as nonsense. The Government in fact adopted the wage freeze which the Liberal-National Party Government had introduced. I congratulate the Government on its ability to extend that wage pause for a period longer than I suspect that the Liberal-National Party would have been able to persuade the unions to accept . By dint of a very clever public relations summit conference and some clever manipulation of dates, in fact the Government has managed to maintain the pause right up until this month. I congratulate the Government on that cleverness. It certainly has been of advantage to the economy of this country that the Government was able to maintain that pause right through until this month. I think it was a great pity that it has not been able to maintain the pause right through until the end of the year. Of course, the pause has now been recognised as being meritorious, notwithstanding the Labor Party's criticism of the legislation when it was introduced. In the course of the last election campaign there was continued criticism of it and references by Senator Walsh to discredited governments, discredited Treasurers and discredited policies. In fact, not only has the Australian Labor Party in government adopted the policy but also, as I mentioned, it has now been recognised as a meritorious piece of legislation. In support of that, I quote from a briefing for the National Economic Summit Conference prepared by the National Institute of Labour Studies at Flinders University which stated that 'wage rises averaging 16.4 per cent were agreed to in an atmosphere of optimism about the economy which was now known to be unfounded'. Professor Richard Blandy and Dr David Harrison of the Institute said that the combined effects of inflation and the wages pause could only be expected to redress the balance if no wage catch-up was permitted. Of course, it was very important that there be no wage catch-up, but this government seems to have succumbed to the pressure of unions to accept at leat some partial catch-up by agreeing to indexation. In support also of my claim that the pause is recognised as meritorious, I quote from the Reserve Bank of Australia's annual report for the year ending 30 June 1983. It states:

In the preceding couple of years Australia, against the tide of events in other industrial countries, had performed quite strongly. Unfortunately, increases in wage incomes in those years had been based on excessive confidence that Australia's good fortune would continue.
Later it states:
More responsible attitudes to wage demands developed-
That is throughout the year-
and there was widespread support for the 'pause' in wages from about the middle of the year.

Of course, as my colleague Senator Messner pointed out, when the Labor Party discovered that there was widespread support for the pause-the discovery being made as a result of certain polls conducted around the nation-it decided to adopt the previous Government's policy. Again in support of that statement I quote from this year's Budget Papers presented by this Government. On page 25 of Budget Paper No. 1 it states:
Average award rates of pay increased only marginally-by 0.3 per cent-between January 1983 and June 1983, which suggests that the 'wages pause' was effective during this period.

The pause was aimed at helping redress the balance between wages and profits and between the employed and the unemployed. It was aimed firstly at ourselves and all wage and salary earners. It took nothing away except increases. It did not cut back; it just provided that there would be no increases. The legislation provided that the moneys thus saved would go to provide new jobs for the unemployed. I suggest to the Senate that it was economically appropriate at the time. It was idealistic, it was accepted by the people of Australia and, in fact , it worked.

Now, under pressure from this Government, non-public sector wages have been freed up by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's granting a 4.3 per cent rise for the March and June quarters. Of course, the Opposition parties will not oppose this legislation repealing the previous Salaries and Wages Pause Act because they do not wish that the public sector should continue to make a sacrifice while this Government believes that the non-public sector should have its increase. It is clear that the decision of the Commission is certainly fraught with grave danger and has been subjected to much criticism by those who apply their minds to the results of these things within the community. I return to the Australian Financial Review and this time quote from its editorial of Monday 26 September 1983 which states:

The Arbitration Commission has a real talent for getting things wrong. It introduced indexation under the last Labor Government and insisted on maintaining it through the worst of the recession of the mid-1970s, thus impeding labour market adjustment. Then, when the resources investment boom came along, wages took off from this high maintained base.

This time around it has reintroduced full indexation at a time when the economy is in the depths of a severe recession and overall would tend to fall in real terms. . . . Industrial peace is a major consideration.

The documentation presented to the national economic conference in April this year made absolutely clear that the lower the rate of growth of wages, the faster would be the rate of growth of the economy and employment and subsequent declines in rates of unemployment.

The unions made clear that they would not have tolerated a continuation of the wages freeze. In other words, they expressed a preference for increased money wages and higher unemployment instead of reduced money wages and reduced unemployment.

What will all that do to the unemployed and those whose jobs are at risk in this country? Clearly, employers cannot keep paying increased wages on the basis of increases in the consumer price index. Employers can pay their wages only if there is an increase in production and profits to enable them to meet the expense. If they cannot meet the expense of the increased wages they will have no choice but to shed labour. That is what employers have been doing for the last 18 months or two years at an ever- increasing rate and under this policy which this Government has foisted upon the people of Australia they will continue to do so. After the wage case decision, the Director-General of the Confederation of Australian Industry, Mr Bryan Noakes, said:
There is no justification for this decision either in economics or in logic.
The annual cost of this increase to industry is the equivalent of the annual wages bill for more than 200,000 full-time employees.
The increase will make it even more difficult for employers to maintain existing jobs, and will act as a severe disincentive to any increase in employment levels.

I understand the problems of this Government endeavouring to maintain industrial peace, but it is clear that it has abandoned the unemployed. The continuation of this pause to the end of this year would have helped the unemployed of this nation. They will maintain the level of real wages that they have managed to squeeze out of this economy in the past and the unemployed will make the sacrifice. TALK.START.PARA: —I again raise the question of the wine excise, which I have raised on three previous occasions during adjournment debates. The Senate knows that the Budget proposed a wine excise of $2.61 per litre of alcohol to apply to grape spirit introduced to fortified wine. I am sure that when this excise was proposed the Government did not appreciate the full ramifications of its effects on the grape growing and wine industries. I am sure also that the Government had no appreciation of the impact of the new tax and of the fact that it would fall upon parts of Australia, and particularly South Australia, in an inordinately disproportionate way. The new tax is designed to attach itself only to grape spirit, and it is very clear that it does not touch the wide range of wines, a tax which it was rumoured might be introduced just before the Budget finally came down. I point out to the Senate that even though no broad wine tax was in fact introduced, the effect of a tax such as the excise on grape spirit is much the same in that it restricts the growth of the whole wine industry. It is well known in the wine and grape growing industry that when there are surpluses in grape production in good years wine makers buy in substantial quantities of grapes which they make into spirit and store away so that it can be drawn upon in bad years to catch up the shortfall.

SPEECH.PARA: This not only has a very important and significant effect for the wine maker himself in levelling out the supply of grape spirit for various purposes but also has the effect of providing income for the small grape growers and block owners in years when there is a surplus rather than having their quota for grapes cut off in such a way as to lose the income from that. Of course that tends to provide them with a levelling effect over the years in which they might have shortages or when because of seasonal factors they are unable to produce enough grapes for production when the wineries really need it. In that way the wine industry over the years has sought to even out its problems of production and in fact has looked after itself. That has been a very significant feature of the industry, in particular to the brandy industry, which is very closely related to the grape spirit industry.

The impact of this new wine excise tax is to reduce the capacity of wine makers to buy in grapes and make them into spirit because at the point at which they actually turn that spirit into a product or add it to ports or something else then it is immediately taxed. That tax of course has to be found in terms of cash within seven days of production, yet the product may lay dead for some eight, 10 or 15 years before the cash from its sale is finally realised. That amounts to a very substantial investment which will cost, at today's interest rates, significant amounts on top of the original outlay. Indeed it is very easy to imagine a circumstance in which a fairly large operator, who makes high quality ports, for instance, would be up for several million dollars in extra outlays over the next eight or 10 years while the product is maturing and until it is finally sold on the market.

The impact of that is very significant and will obviously lead to a reduction in the capacity of the industry to absorb grapes and crush them for spirit, to the point where the industry itself has estimated that the impact of the excise will decrease the possible market for the product of fortified wines-that is, sherries, ports and wines of that kind-by up to 40 per cent in the next financial year. As we all know that would be absolutely disastrous for the industry and would have very significant effects for regional parts of South Australia. I mention particularly the Riverland districts of South Australia, the Murrumbidgee areas around Griffith in New South Wales and the Sunraysia districts around Mildura in Victoria. Those matters are of great significance to my State in particular and I rise to bring again to the Government's attention the problems relating to that industry.

It is true that the Government has recognised the force of this argument which has been put by members of parliament-I instance Mr Neil Andrew, the member for Wakefield who has spoken on this matter in the House of Representatives and myself amongst other senators from South Australia-who have constantly brought these problems to the attention of the Government. It is true that the Government has acknowledged those problems and in fact has taken some action in recent weeks to alleviate them. The way the Government chose to do that was to reduce the rate of excise from $2.61 per litre of alcohol to $1.50. While that certainly is welcome it does not alleviate the problem of financing the cost of excise over the long period of maturation of fortified wines, which is the basis of the industry's complaint. It certainly does not attempt in any way to look at the problems of the industry looking after itself, and in fact will make the industry more dependent upon government in due course.

I conclude by seeking to incorporate in Hansard a telex which has been forwarded to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by the Wine and Brandy Co-operative Producers of Australia, particularly from South Australia, which sets out the argument quite clearly and which seeks further Government reconsideration of this problem, not so much towards the reduction of the rate of excise but rather a reconsideration by the Government of the manner in which it collects the tax which does and will have disastrous consequences upon the industry. I have had no time to show the telex to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise in the adjournment debate tonight a matter similar to that raised by Senator Messner. However, it refers to far fewer producers and it is a problem of much longer standing. Indeed, Senator Messner, in his capacity as the then Minister Assisting the Treasurer, appears in the story that I am about to relate yet again. On 23 September last year I raised the problem of those few producers in Australia who produce wine made from fruits other than grapes. Coupled with that is the problem of the five producers only in that category and the other five who produce wine made from Australian honey. This problem dates back a long way, to a decision of the Commissioner of Taxation that the definition of Australian wine is that it is wine made from grapes. The problem with that definition is, I think, evident since no dictionary and no encyclopaedia makes such a stipulation. In the latest edition of the handbook of the industry, The Technology of Wine Making, no distinction is drawn; all are considered to be wine. The Macquarie Dictionary definition of wine states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the juice, fermented or unfermented, of various other fruits or plants, used as a beverage . . .

The fruit juices are looked after in relation to the sales tax provisions. There is an exemption from sales tax for Australian wine but the interpretation given by the Commissioner has meant that those few producers, particularly the ones in my State-of course I am concerned for all-who produce from Australian fruits that are produced nowhere else in the world suffer from this massive disadvantage which is currently at 20 per cent. As I mentioned at the beginning of my speech, I have pursued this matter for some time with the Minister in the previous Government and Senator Messner, in his capacity as then Minister Assisting the Treasurer, wrote last year that the granting of sales tax exemption must be taken account of in the overall economic strategy. Presumably the letter that was written was meant to be a joke inasmuch as the amount we are looking at is some few thousand dollars only in the totality of what is going on . Senator Peter Baume, who was the Minister at the table at the time of that adjournment debate, said that he would take this matter to the then Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —And indeed did so, Senator.

—He may very well have done so. He assures me that he did, and I am sure that was the case. However, the then Treasurer failed to give any response. Following that, on 5 July this year I wrote again to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of the new Government, raising the matter yet again. Again there was no response, not even an acknowledgment that the letter had been received.
—Was that this year?
—That was on 5 July 1983 to the Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating. I then raised a question in the Senate on 8 September with the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Walsh, who said that he would:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . convey the question to the Treasurer for consideration by the Government at some future time.

Presumably, that consideration has not yet taken place. At some stage quite shortly we will discuss the sales tax legislation again. Certainly, I will not give up the fight on behalf of these few producers who have been discriminated against in the most unjust way for some inordinate amount of time.

I add a further reason for my belief that the exemption from sales tax which this Government has now determined ought to be given to producers of Australian wines made from grapes ought to be given to these particular producers. They are happy to have their products included in whatever provision is made for Australian wines, whether they be taxed and at whatever level, as long as they are taxed in the same way as wines made from grapes. They are not looking for any special consideration. They are merely looking for equality of consideration .

Furthermore, these 10 producers are positioned to take advantage of and contribute to the tourist industry. They have tourist potential. The major ones, in particular, operate in that way. They take advantage of the revenue earning tourist dollar in the areas in which they are positioned. Many tourists, when in those vicinities, are happy to take advantage of a product which is not readily available throughout the rest of Australia and, when they return home, to use that product as part promotion. I support this Government in its high profile attempt to stimulate the tourist industry, as would all Australians. Indeed, when one looks at the balance of payments in relation to tourism one sees that we are currently suffering an enormous loss in that area. Many more tourists leave Australia than visit Australia. I am quite sure that every honourable senator would support the Government in what it is attempting to do to promote internal tourism.

I stress that the companies about which I am talking are small companies; they are not big league operations. Only a few thousand dollars would be involved in the totality of Australia if they were to be exempted from sales tax. While that may seem a small matter to raise in the Senate, I believe that those small businessmen need this type of support. It is interesting that they are not coming to the Government asking for a special handout. They are not coming to the Government to plead for massive protection support. They are merely asking to be treated on the same basis as companies producing other wines made from Australian fruits. I believe that that is a reasonable request. I had hoped that we would by now have had a reasonable response from the Government on this issue of including such companies, because it is one of equity and nothing else.

There have been some mutterings of other ramifications, such as the problem with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. I believe that this Government has an obligation to support those industries to the extent of the amount they would stand to lose. After looking at the amount forwarded to the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited, I am quite sure that an amount of $3,000 or $4,000 would not break the bank, but it would restore equity in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that I did not hear the beginning of Senator Messner's speech. I thought that the debate was to start at 6.30 p.m. However, he has informed me that the substance of his speech was virtually the same as the telex he had incorporated in Hansard and covered the same points. I will say something about those in a moment. Senator Macklin asked me a question on this matter a couple of weeks ago , to which I said I would try to get a response. I apologise for having been unable to get one as yet. If I remember correctly I also said at that time that there were a number of anomalies in the Sales Tax Act, some of which were corrected by the previous Government in its last couple of Budgets and some of which were adjusted by the present Government in the recent Budget. I believe that there is a prima facie case for making some adjustment, but I would not like to make any commitments as to the direction in which such adjustment should be made.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to Senator Messner's comments, it is certainly arguable that if a tax is to be imposed on wine of any sort a sales tax type of tax is both more equitable in income distribution consequences and also less distorting at the production end than a tax related to the alcoholic content of the wine or fortified wine. I can certainly see that the argument that sales taxes would have been preferable to an excise has some validity. However, excises have existed for a very long time on whisky and brandy. Until 1970 excises were imposed on fortifying spirit at a level of $2 a litre which, converted into present day values, is about $8 a litre. Thus, the excise on fortifying spirit reimposed in this Budget and subsequently adjusted to $1.50 a litre is very much lower in real terms than the level of excise that applied until 1970. I observe also that it is extremely low compared with the excise applied to what is almost an identical product, brandy, which is, from memory, about $16 a litre of alcohol.

Therefore, although that is an argument to be put, I think the tone of the telex that Senator Messner has incorporated is certainly exaggerated and, in parts, goes close to being hysterical. I will deal with a couple of specific points made in that telex. In one paragraph it was stated:
We would also ask, why has not the Government extended the excise to imported fortified wine? Surely imported product is equally deserving of a like penalty.

The fact is that imported fortified wine attracts sales tax of 20 per cent, which has been increased substantially in the 1981 and 1982 Budgets as a result of other sales tax changes. In those two Budgets it was increased from 15 per cent to 20 per cent. As Senator Macklin indicated, there are GATT implications associated with the imposition of a general sales tax on wine. Indeed, the interpretation of the legal position under GATT which has been given to me is that if a general sales tax were to be introduced on Australian wine the rate of sales tax applied to imported wine would have to be identical. That, of course, would put the Australian industry in a disadvantaged position vis-a-vis imports relative to where it is now.

It is difficult to reconcile with the facts the assertion in the telex that the 'Government's imposition has been made so selective and so discriminatory'- discriminatory, allegedly, against producers of fortifying spirits and fortified wines. The facts are: First, until 1970 an excise of in present value dollar terms $8 a litre was applied; secondly, an almost identical product, namely brandy, carries excise at the rate of, I think, $16 a litre; and thirdly, imports are in fact subject to a sales tax of 20 per cent whereas the Australian product is free from sales tax. Moreover, if it is accepted-and I do not necessarily pass judgment in this direction-that a product containing a higher concentration of alcohol ought to be subject to a higher rate of tax than a product containing a lesser concentration of alcohol, then, of course, the case for applying some form of taxation on fortified wines has to be stronger than the case for applying some form of taxation on wine in general.

Finally, to put the final effects of the tax in perspective, with a 10 per cent rate of fortification-that is, 10 per cent by volume of alcohol added to the product-at this present level the excise amounts to something less than 15c for a 750 millilitre bottle. It is likely to impact in ad valorem terms. Unfortunately, it tends to fall more heavily on the lower priced bulk product than the higher priced products. But it may well be that whatever tax is imposed on this industry ought to be imposed in a different way from the way that was chosen at this time. That is a question to which I would expect that the Government will address itself at some future time. But the assertion that this is a particularly selective and discriminatory tax against this particular section of the wine industry is, I say again, somewhat difficult to reconcile with the low level of the excise being imposed relative to that which has applied to the same product in recent years, relative to that which applies to an almost identical product, brandy, and relative to that which is applied to imported wines, fortified or otherwise.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is a high percentage of the decisions of the Repatriation Boards and Commission set aside by the Repatriation Review Tribunal (RRT); if so, why.
(2) Are many genuine claims being disallowed at the earlier hearing by the Boards or the Commission delegates; if so, why.

(3) Has the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, or the Department of Veterans' Affairs, requested the Repatriation Advisory Committee to ascertain, or comment on, why such a high percentage of valid repatriation claims are rejected at Board and Commission hearings; if not, does the Minister intend to undertake such investigations.

(4) Is the recent Departmental policy of opposing appeals, before the RRT, with highly qualified and trained advocates, the only positive action taken to reduce the extremely large number of successful appeals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the 12 months to 24 June 1983, the Repatriation Review Tribunal set aside 89.2 per cent of the decisions which it reviewed where the Commission had refused a claim for pension. In addition, during the same period, the Repatriation Review Tribunal set aside 69.8 per cent of the decisions it reviewed concerning the assessment of the rate of pension and service pension eligibility.

Several factors contributed to the high percentage of decisions on claims for pensions being set aside. In many cases, material evidence is not introduced until the matter comes before the Tribunal. In other cases, the refusal of the claim by a Repatriation Board and the Repatriation Commission had been without the benefit of subsequent decisions by the High Court, Federal Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The mean time taken to process entitlement applications in 1982-83 was 737 days. This means that most of the appeals decided were lodged before the High Court handed down its decision in the Law case.

There has also been a difference between the Tribunal and the Commission in the interpretation of certain legislative provisions as they apply to cases where the aetiology of the incapacity is unknown. Three decisions recently handed down by the Federal Court have supported the Commission's views.
When the Tribunal sets aside a decision concerning the assessment of a rate of pension, it may substitute either a lower rate of pension or a higher rate.
(2) For the reasons set out in the answer to (1), the answer is no.

The beneficial provisions of the legislation are designed to facilitate acceptance of claims where there is some evidence of fact which might fulfil the conditions of eligibility. All determining authorities are fully aware of their responsibilities under the legislation. The acceptance rate for entitlement claims at the Repatriation Board level in 1982-83 was 70.1 per cent and for appeals to the Repatriation Commission 49.1 per cent. The acceptance rate for applications for increase in existing pensions at the Repatriation Board level in 1982-83 was 76.3 per cent. These acceptance rates demonstrate that a generous approach is being taken at these primary determining levels.

(3) The Advisory Committee on Repatriation Legislation Review is concerned with the major task of reviewing the repartiation legislation for the purposes of consolidation and simplification. This question has not been specifically referred to it.
The Administrative Review Council has reviewed the determining structure. It is expected that its report will be available in the near future.

(4) The Repatriation Commission is charged with the administration of the Act and does not see its role as one of trying to reduce successful applications but , in this area, as one of ensuring that correct decisions are made within the meaning of the law. The Commission has appeared in a small number of Tribunal cases, but has not had the resources available to it to appear in any great number of cases. As mentioned in the reply to question (1), the Commission has successfully pursued appeals to the Federal Court. The decisions handed down to date are in accord with the principles the Commission has adopted in the determination of matters before it.

A good deal of effort has gone into ensuring that Repatriation Boards and Repatriation Commission delegates reach decisions in accordance with the law. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 13 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps has the Government taken to ensure that errors in navigation, such as are presumed to have occurred in the Korean Airlines Flight 007 disaster , cannot happen in aircraft flying under Australian flags or in international aircraft.
(2) Are sufficient fail-safe mechanisms installed with adequate back-up systems .
(3) Has a procedure been enforced to ensure that only a correct course can be placed in the inertial navigation system and does the procedure entail cross- checking by other crew members.
(4) Do Qantas and major domestic aircraft carry Omega navigation aids and is there an adequate procedure established for cross-checking the correct course and bearings.
(5) What international conferences have been held since the Korean Airlines disaster to tighten navigation procedures; if so, what role has Australia played .

(6) What compensation is available to the estates of the Australian victims either from claims upon the Korean airline or from any other source apart from any request to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics for compensation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Aviation checks the operations manuals of each Australian airline for the acceptability of its prescribed cockpit procedures. In addition, periodic checks for adherence to these procedures are conducted by departmental officers during in-flight inspections of the airlines. The manuals of international operators seeking to operate to Australia are also submitted to the Department for checking prior to the issue of licences to those operators. It is believed that steps additional to these are not necessary. We cannot influence the way in which international operators conduct their activities outside Australian airspace although the procedures specified by airlines, both here and abroad, are very similar.

(2) The inertial navigation systems-INS-installed in airline aircraft usually consist of two or three separate inertial units to provide redundancy. The systems are not of themselves fail safe, but failure warning is provided and crew checks are designed to ensure the early detection of discrepancies so that alternative procedures or systems can be implemented to ensure the safe completion of a flight.

(3) Although it is possible to insert incorrect information into an inertial navigation system, crew procedures around the world are designed to prevent such an incorrect input remaining undetected. These procedures require the global position of waypoints and the details of tracks and distances to be fully verified prior to departure and re-checked on each route segment during flight by at least two pilots.

(4) Only the Ansett B727 and B737 aircraft carry VLF/Omega equipment for navigation purposes. The crew procedures in respect of this equipment are similar to those used with inertial navigation systems and also rely on formal crew cross checking and verification requirements.

(5) The Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization met in an extraordinary session on 15 September 1983 and passed a resolution directing the Secretary-General of ICAO to instigate an investigation into the disaster. The Council directed its subsidiary body, the Air Navigation Commission, to examine ways in which a recurrence of such a tragic accident might be prevented. Australia and a number of other countries jointly sponsored this resolution. The ICAO triennial Assembly is currently being held in Montreal, and the Australian delegation to the Assembly will support fully any initiatives to strengthen the security of international civil aviation.

(6) Any claim for compensation from the Korean airline, insurance companies, employers and sources other than the Soviet Union is a private legal matter. I am informed that the Department of Foreign Affairs advised the families of the Australian victims to seek legal advice and I understand that they have done so. The Government's priority is to obtain prompt and adequate compensation from the USSR for a grave violation of international law and to ensure through appropriate action in international forums that such incidents are never repeated.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 22 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the present uncertainties about the performance and unreliability of the present Landsat series of satellites, referred to in Answer to Question No. 323, Hansard, 15 September 1983, page 750.
(2) For what reason or reasons, is the upgrading of the resources satellites unjustified.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Of the four earth resources satellites launched by the United States of America only Landsat 4 remains operational and only partly so. I am informed that it has experienced a failure of half of the solar cell array which provides electrical power to the satellite. Problems with the remaining power capacity are becoming evident and could cause the satellite to become unserviceable at any time. In addition the capability to transmit the high resolution thematic mapper data to ground stations failed shortly after launch.

(2) I assume that the honourable senator is referring to upgrading the Australian Landsat station-not the satellites. As I said in answer to the honourable senator's previous question, the Government decided that, in view of more pressing demands for funding in the recent Budget context, the upgrade could not be justified at that time. However, it could be considered at a later date depending upon the availability of satellite data and the cost recovery performance of the station.
